{{news release|1=article|date=October 2017}} {{essay-like|date=October 2017}} '''Dynamic consent''' is a new approach to consent that engages individuals in decisions about how their personal information should be used. It is a personalised, digital communication interface that enables two-way communication between participants and researchers, and puts participants at the centre of decision making.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=24801761 | doi=10.1038/ejhg.2014.71 | volume=23 | title=Dynamic consent: a patient interface for twenty-first century research networks | pmc=4130658 | year=2015 | journal=Eur. J. Hum. Genet. | pages=141‚Äì6 | last1 = Kaye | first1 = J | last2 = Whitley | first2 = EA | last3 = Lund | first3 = D | last4 = Morrison | first4 = M | last5 = Teare | first5 = H | last6 = Melham | first6 = K}}</ref> It is a practical example of how software can be developed to give research participants control over how their data is used.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wee|first1=Richman|last2=Henaghan|first2=Mark|last3=Winship|first3=Ingrid|title=Dynamic consent in the digital age of biology: online initiatives and regulatory considerations|journal=Journal of Primary Health Care|date=December 2013|volume=5|issue=4|page=341|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/HC/pdf/HC13341|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref>
== Background == Researchers are required to obtain [[informed consent]] from potential participants before any [[research]] begins ‚Äì this is a fundamental principle of medical research as laid out in the [[Declaration of Helsinki]]. Traditionally this has been done through a paper consent form which is accompanied by a subject information sheet that describes the risks and benefits of being involved in the research. Increasingly, this also outlines how an individual‚Äôs data will be protected and their [[privacy]] maintained. This constitutes a formal agreement that specifies how a [[research participant]]‚Äôs data will be used in that particular study. Participants should be informed about the purpose(s) for which their data will (or may) be used; where it will be stored; the expected retention time; if any other parties are involved; the amount and the sensitivity of the information exchanged; whether the data will be shared onward to yet other parties; whether the consent to use these data can be revoked. Consent to [[data processing]] is also a requirement of [https://www.gov.uk/data-protection/the-data-protection-act data protection] and [[Information privacy|privacy]] laws in most countries. Traditionally, participants have obtained details of how their data will be used from patient information sheets and face-to-face interactions with researchers or healthcare staff.
However, now both medical research and data processing are changing through developments in [[information communication technology]], especially the [[internet]] with examples including genetic databases and registries, [[electronic health records]], [[biobanks]], and online digital services and databases. More and more data is being collected online and being stored in large [[data set]]s with the intention for them to be used by many researchers, research groups and institutions for a variety of purposes. These include different research projects, as well as public health assessments, [[marketing]], and the design of [[algorithms]] and [[data mining]].
The collection and use of data in this way raises some challenges. Firstly with regard to privacy: can participants' data and identity truly be [[Anonymity|anonymised]] and sensitive data be kept safe and [[Confidentiality|confidential]]? Individuals, in general, are not aware of how their [[personal information]] is used, for what purpose and which parties have a copy. They are not usually given the opportunity to declare their specific consents and privacy-related personal data management preferences. Secondly, with regard to consent: informed consent requires a person to know in advance what they are agreeing to and what the likely risks and benefits of agreeing will be. But with these large, linked data sets, it is often not clear at the time someone is asked to consent how their data will be used in the future.
This is known as a broad consent or a blanket consent. Blanket consent means that a person effectively agrees to permit any and all uses of their data once it is provided. Broad consent is more common and involves agreeing to a broad set of potential future uses under a particular governance framework. Broad consent has become the standard practice in many genetic registries and biobanks<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wma.net/policies-post/wma-declaration-of-taipei-on-ethical-considerations-regarding-health-databases-and-biobanks/|title=WMA - The World Medical Association-WMA Declaration of Taipei on Ethical Considerations regarding Health Databases and Biobanks|website=www.wma.net|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref>. Its legal and ethical adequacy has been questioned.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Timothy Caulfield|last2=Jane Kaye|date=2009-09-01|title=Broad Consent in Biobanking: Reflections on Seemingly Insurmountable Dilemmas|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/096853320901000201|journal=Medical Law International|language=en|volume=10|issue=2|pages=85‚Äì100|doi=10.1177/096853320901000201|issn=0968-5332}}</ref> In addition, consent is still frequently done as a one-off procedure with a paper form for participants to sign. These forms are often lost or filed away, and over time people forget what they have consented to and why.
== What is dynamic consent?== Dynamic consent is a personalised digital interface to facilitate participant engagement in clinical and research activities over time. It seeks to address some of the issues raised by the traditional, paper-based, static consent approach, where consent must be obtained for all future activities in a face to face interview. Dynamic consent operates through a secure IT interface for consent and communication that enables participants to view a digital record of their consent decisions, subsequent to their initial agreement. Some versions of dynamic consent also have the functionality for people to personalise according to their preferences, which can be changed at any time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Platform for Engaging Everyone Responsibly|url=http://www.geneticalliance.org/programs/biotrust/peer/|website=Genetic Alliance|accessdate=17 January 2017}}</ref>
Further, dynamic consent aims to put people in control of their data and how it is used, reflecting patient-centric initiatives happening elsewhere in medical research.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dwamena|first=Francesca|last2=Holmes-Rovner|first2=Margaret|last3=Gaulden|first3=Carolyn M|last4=Jorgenson|first4=Sarah|last5=Sadigh|first5=Gelareh|last6=Sikorskii|first6=Alla|last7=Lewin|first7=Simon|last8=Smith|first8=Robert C|last9=Coffey|first9=John|date=2012-12-12|title=Interventions for providers to promote a patient-centred approach in clinical consultations|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/14651858.cd003267.pub2|journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|doi=10.1002/14651858.cd003267.pub2|issn=1465-1858}}</ref> Through the tool, participants can consent to new projects or change their consent choices; they can complete surveys and receive information about research findings. Preferences are linked with a participant's samples and data and so if these are shared, so too are the individual's preferences. It enables people to give a range of different kinds of consent, for example, a broad consent to low-risk epidemiological research or an explicit consent to a new, high-risk proposal. This flexibility is enabled by the digital interface where preferences can be changed in line with new situations.
Dynamic consent may facilitate recruitment in research, as information is provided to potential participants in a user-friendly and standardised way across research sites and irrespective of the participants' geographical location.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Budin-Lj√∏sne et al|first1=I|title=Dynamic Consent: a potential solution to some of the challenges of modern biomedical research.|journal=BMC Medical Ethics|date=25 Jan 2017|issue=18(1):4.|url=https://bmcmedethics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12910-016-0162-9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pang|first=Patrick Cheong-Iao|last2=Chang|first2=Shanton|last3=Verspoor|first3=Karin|last4=Clavisi|first4=Ornella|date=2018-10-30|title=The Use of Web-Based Technologies in Health Research Participation: Qualitative Study of Consumer and Researcher Experiences|url=https://www.jmir.org/2018/10/e12094/|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|language=en|volume=20|issue=10|pages=e12094|doi=10.2196/12094|issn=1438-8871}}</ref> Dynamic consent enables two-way, ongoing communication between researchers and research participants. For instance, research participants are able to upload additional health data, or researchers may inform participants about new research opportunities or findings. Such ongoing interface may increase the participants' understanding of research and positively impact retention rates.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Budin-Lj√∏sne|first=Isabelle|last2=Teare|first2=Harriet J. A.|last3=Kaye|first3=Jane|last4=Beck|first4=Stephan|last5=Bentzen|first5=Heidi Beate|last6=Caenazzo|first6=Luciana|last7=Collett|first7=Clive|last8=D‚ÄôAbramo|first8=Flavio|last9=Felzmann|first9=Heike|date=2017-01-25|title=Dynamic Consent: a potential solution to some of the challenges of modern biomedical research|url=https://doi.org/10.1186/s12910-016-0162-9|journal=BMC Medical Ethics|volume=18|pages=4|doi=10.1186/s12910-016-0162-9|issn=1472-6939}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pang|first=Patrick Cheong-Iao|last2=Chang|first2=Shanton|last3=Verspoor|first3=Karin|last4=Clavisi|first4=Ornella|date=2018-10-30|title=The Use of Web-Based Technologies in Health Research Participation: Qualitative Study of Consumer and Researcher Experiences|url=https://www.jmir.org/2018/10/e12094/|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|language=en|volume=20|issue=10|pages=e12094|doi=10.2196/12094|issn=1438-8871}}</ref>
== What makes dynamic consent dynamic? == This digital interface is dynamic because individuals can: * give different kinds of consents (e.g. broad, explicit, specific) to different activities * change their consent preferences to the use of their samples and information in real time in response to their changing circumstances * enrol in new studies or engage in self-reported research * receive up to date information on how their samples and data are being used and on the progress and outcomes of research * tailor the way they receive information, change these preferences over time and have a record of all transactions in one place * be contacted easily by researchers when there is a protocol change, their opinion is needed or a new consent is required.<ref>Teare, HJA; Morrison, M; Whitley, EA; Kaye, J (2015). Towards 'Engagement 2.0': Insights from a study of dynamic consent with biobank participants. Digital Health 0(0): 1-13. [http://dhj.sagepub.com/content/spdhj/1/2055207615605644.full.pdf doi:10.1177/2055207615605644]</ref> == History of dynamic consent == === First Genetic Trust === In 2001 First Genetic Trust (FGT) put forward the idea that they act as a 'broker' of genetic information. They would be a third party between people taking part in research that involved their genetic data and those carrying out the research. FGT recommended a method that would protect 'the confidentiality of individual medical and genetic information, allowing access to select information and the use or application of an individual's DNA only when the patient has given specific consent.'<ref>{{cite web|title=First Genetic Trust selects HP as technology partner|url=http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press/2002/020211a.html|website=Hewlett Packard (HP) Co. Newsroom|accessdate=14 September 2012|date=11 February 2002}}</ref> This system has characteristics of dynamic consent before the term was coined.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wee|first1=Richman|title=Dynamic consent in the digital age of biology|journal=Journal of Primary Health Care|date=September 2013|volume=5|issue=3|page=259|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/hc/pdf/HC13259|accessdate=19 January 2017}}</ref>
=== EnCoRe === The EnCoRe project ‚Äì Ensuring Consent and Revocation ‚Äì began in 2008 and ran until 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the EnCoRe project website!|url=http://www.hpl.hp.com/breweb/encoreproject/index.html|website=EnCoRe|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> It was funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]), the Economic and Social Research Council ([[ESRC]]) and the UK government's [[Technology Strategy Board]]. Institutional partners for the project were [[Hewlett-Packard]] (and specifically the Hewlett-Packard Systems Security Lab in Bristol), the [[Warwick Manufacturing Group]] at the [[University of Warwick]], [[QinetiQ]], [https://www.hwcomms.com/ HW Communications], [https://www.ndph.ox.ac.uk/research/centre-for-health-law-and-emerging-technologies-helex HeLEX] from the [[University of Oxford]] and the [[London School of Economics]].
The project's aim was to give individuals more control over any personal data they disclose to organisations, with an overall vision to make giving and revoking consent as reliable and easy as turning a tap on and off. This was an attempt to tackle the lack of any legal requirement for organisations to obtain consent before using personal data about individuals. EnCoRe aimed to enable people to determine what their information is used for, who it is shared with and for how long and where it is stored.
Three case studies were carried out as part of the EnCore project, each with different requirements for consent and revocation. A technical architecture was produced for each scenario, setting out all the functions needed for the management (including capture and revocation) and enforcement of individuals' consents. The three reports are publicly available online.<ref>{{cite web|title=Public deliverables, papers and other publications|url=http://www.hpl.hp.com/breweb/encoreproject/deliverables.html|website=EnCoRe|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref>
It was in the EnCoRe project that the term 'dynamic consent' was coined by Professor Jane Kaye's team at the University of Oxford and become one of the outputs of the EnCoRe project. It is now used to describe this new way of obtaining consent.
=== InBank === Over time, the focus of dynamic consent has shifted from simply enabling participants to change their consent preferences to incorporating it as part of a larger apparatus that facilitates communication between participants and researchers or health professionals. The InBank team at the [[University of Manchester]] looked at dynamic consent as a way of collecting and sharing [[electronic health records]]. The work was UK-focused, considering dynamic consent in the context of the [[NHS]] and positioning it as a device to increase or restore public trust. The public scandal over the [[care.data]] initiative was positioned as evidence of a deficit in trust, and equally that it showed a lack of transparent and accountable governance of people's personal medical records in the UK.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=Hawys|last2=Spencer|first2=Karen|last3=Sanders|first3=Caroline|last4=Lund|first4=David|last5=Whitley|first5=Edgar|last6=Kaye|first6=Jane|last7=Dixon|first7=William|title=Viewpoint. Dynamic Consent: A Possible Solution to Improve Patient Confidence and Trust in How Electronic Patient Records Are Used in Medical Research|journal=JMIR Medical Informatics|date=2015|volume=3|issue=1|doi=10.2196/medinform.3525|page=e3}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dixon|first1=William|last2=Spencer|first2=Karen|last3=Williams|first3=Hawys|last4=Sanders|first4=Caroline|last5=Lund|first5=David|last6=Whitley|first6=Edgar|last7=Kaye|first7=Jane|title=A dynamic model of patient consent to sharing of medical record data|journal=BMJ|date=2014|page=348|doi=10.1136/bmj.g1294|volume=348}}</ref>
== Dynamic consent in practice == There are a number of examples across Europe of where dynamic consent is being used in research projects. One of these is the [https://research.ndorms.ox.ac.uk/rudy/ RUDY] Study - a study of rare diseases led by researchers at the [http://www.ox.ac.uk/ University of Oxford].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Teare|first=Harriet J. A.|last2=Hogg|first2=Joanna|last3=Kaye|first3=Jane|last4=Luqmani|first4=Raashid|last5=Rush|first5=Elaine|last6=Turner|first6=Alison|last7=Watts|first7=Laura|last8=Williams|first8=Melanie|last9=Javaid|first9=M. Kassim|date=2017-04-26|title=The RUDY study: using digital technologies to enable a research partnership|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ejhg201757|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|language=En|volume=25|issue=7|pages=816|doi=10.1038/ejhg.2017.57}}</ref> RUDY is an internet-based platform that enables registration and capture of patient reported outcome measures ([[Patient-reported outcome|PROMs]]) and events to be done online within a dynamic consent framework.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Javaid|first1=MK|last2=Forestier-Zhang|first2=L|last3=Watts|first3=L|last4=Turner|first4=A|last5=Ponte|first5=C|last6=Teare|first6=H|last7=Gray|first7=D|last8=Gray|first8=N|last9=Popert|first9=R|last10=Hogg|first10=J|last11=Barrett|first11=J|last12=Pinedo-Villanueva|first12=R|last13=Cooper|first13=C|last14=Eastell|first14=R|last15=Bishop|first15=N|last16=Luqmani|first16=R|last17=Wordsworth|first17=P|last18=Kaye|first18=J|title=The RUDY study platform ‚Äì a novel approach to patient driven research in rare musculoskeletal diseases|journal=Orphanet Journal of Rare Diseases|date=2016|volume=11|page=150|doi=10.1186/s13023-016-0528-6}}</ref>
The [http://www.eurac.edu/en/research/health/biomed/projects/Pages/default.aspx CHRIS] (Cooperative Health Research in South Tyrol) Study is a prospective epidemiological study investigating chronic conditions, particularly cardiovascular, metabolic, neurological and psychiatric diseases and was the first study to implement dynamic consent in biobanking.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Piciocchi|first=Cinzia|last2=Ducato|first2=Rossana|last3=Martinelli|first3=Lucia|last4=Perra|first4=Silvia|last5=Tomasi|first5=Marta|last6=Zuddas|first6=Carla|last7=Mascalzoni|first7=Deborah|date=2017-09-18|title=Legal issues in governing genetic biobanks: the Italian framework as a case study for the implications for citizen‚Äôs health through public-private initiatives|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12687-017-0328-2|journal=Journal of Community Genetics|language=en|pages=1‚Äì14|doi=10.1007/s12687-017-0328-2|issn=1868-310X}}</ref> It describes itself as 'a true partnership between the people participating, the staff working in the healthcare system and the research personnel'.<ref>{{cite web|title=The CHRIS Study|url=http://www.eurac.edu/en/research/health/biomed/projects/Pages/default.aspx|website=The CHRIS Study|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> The study is designed to be longitudinal so a dynamic consent process was set up which enables participants to receive ongoing information about the project as well as an interactive consent webpage with dynamic options.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pattaro|first1=Cristian|last2=Gogele|first2=Martin|last3=Mascalzoni|first3=Deborah|last4=Melotti|first4=Roberto|last5=Schwienbacher|first5=Christine|last6=De Grandi|first6=Alessandro|last7=Foco|first7=Luisa|last8=D'Elia|first8=Yuri|last9=Linder|first9=Barbara|last10=Fuchsberger|first10=Christian|last11=Minelli|first11=Cosetta|last12=Egger|first12=Clemens|last13=Kofink|first13=Lisa|last14=Zanigni|first14=Stefano|last15=Schafer|first15=Torsten|last16=Facheris|first16=Maurizio|last17=Sm√°rason|first17=Sigur√∞ur|last18=Rossini|first18=Alessandra|last19=Hicks|first19=Andrew|last20=Weiss|first20=Helmuth|last21=Pramstaller|first21=Peter|title=The Cooperative Health Research in South Tyrol (CHRIS) study: rationale, objectives, and preliminary results|journal=Journal of Translational Medicine|date=2015|volume=13|page=348|doi=10.1186/s12967-015-0704-9|pmc=4635524|pmid=26541195}}</ref>
In the USA, the Platform for Engaging Everyone Responsibly ([http://www.geneticalliance.org/programs/biotrust/peer/ PEER]) has been set up by non-profit health advocacy organisation [[Genetic Alliance]] and software company [https://www.privateaccess.info/ Private Access]. Not only can participants choose to consent to only some aspects of research and not to others, but they can also specify preferences for types of data access by third parties and consent to other activities that are offered, such as the use of their biological samples after death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Platform for Engaging Everyone Responsibly|url=http://www.geneticalliance.org/programs/biotrust/peer/|website=Genetic Alliance|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref>
== Challenges to dynamic consent == Criticisms have been made about dynamic consent including that it is unnecessary. A number of empirical studies that were carried out before dynamic consent was developed, suggested that people are happy to give broad or 'one-off' consent for some kinds of research. For example, a face-to face interview study of 1001 Scottish adults as part of the prospective Scottish Family Health Study genetic database carried out in 2009 found that respondents preferred 'scenarios where consent is only asked for at the start of the study' over options to renew consent every 5 or 10 years.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Haddow|first1=Gill|last2=Cunningham-Burley|first2=Sarah|last3=Murray|first3=Lorraine|title=Can the governance of a population genetic data bank effect recruitment? Evidence from the public consultation of Generation Scotland|journal=Public Understanding of Science|date=April 2010|volume=20|issue=117|doi=10.1177/0963662510361655|url=http://pus.sagepub.com/content/20/1/117|accessdate=24 January 2017|pages=117‚Äì129}}</ref>
Similarly, a survey of US adults published in 2010, reported a preference for a broad, 'one off' consent at the time of donation to a biobank over giving specific consent for each new study.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Christian|last2=L'Heureux|first2=Jamie|last3=Murray|first3=Jeffrey|last4=Winokur|first4=Patricia|last5=Weiner|first5=George|last6=Newbury|first6=Elizabeth|last7=Shinkunas|first7=Laura|last8=Zimmerman|first8=Bridget|journal=Genetics in Medicine|date=2011|volume=13|issue=9|page=821|doi=10.1097/GIM.0b013e31821d2f88|title=Active choice but not too active: Public perspectives on biobank consent models|pmc=3658114}}</ref> A meta-analysis of the qualitative sociological literature on public and patient attitudes to biobanking published 2002-9 reached a similar conclusion: 'few people demanded recurrent, project-specific consent and few wished to place limits on the uses to which their tissue could be put'.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lipworth|first1=Wendy|last2=Forsyth|first2=Rowena|last3=Kerridge|first3=Ian|title=Tissue donation to biobanks: a review of sociological studies|journal=Sociology of Health and Illness|date=2011|volume=33|issue=5|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9566.2011.01342.x|pages=792‚Äì811}}</ref> However, these studies did not present dynamic consent to their respondents as an alternative to a broad consent.
There have been some criticism of dynamic consent by a Norwegian team of researchers, who argued that dynamic consent would be an unwanted burden on participants and a waste of time for researchers. 'In a dynamic consent model, participants will be asked for consent continuously, simply because each new project is a new project. Thus, they will be asked to re-consent both for trivial and essential reasons, and often the former'.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kristin Solum|first1=Steinsbekk|last2=Myskja|first2=Bj√∏rn Ka¬∞re|last3=Solberg|first3=Berge|title=Broad consent versus dynamic consent in biobank research: Is passive participation an ethical problem?|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|date=2013|volume=21|doi=10.1038/ejhg.2012.282|pages=897‚Äì902|pmc=3746258}}</ref> However, this opinion was based on an erroneous understanding of dynamic consent as requiring consent for each new study, rather being able to be tailored to the needs and ethical requirements of a particular study.
Steinsbekk et al. in their publication criticising dynamic consent also argued that rather than increasing the number of people taking part in research, dynamic consent may have the opposite effect. 'Being confronted with the detailed complexity of biomedical research, and being asked again and again for an 'opinion' (a consent), it is likely that at least some people will struggle with feelings of falling short ‚Äì that their own competence or knowledge do not suffice. This could easily be interpreted as a 'lack of respect' for the passive participant, and result in lower participation as people would rather choose to stay away from such studies than face shortcomings.'<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kristin Solum|first1=Steinsbekk|last2=Myskja|first2=Bj√∏rn Ka¬∞re|last3=Solberg|first3=Berge|title=Broad consent versus dynamic consent in biobank research: Is passive participation an ethical problem?|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|date=2013|volume=21|doi=10.1038/ejhg.2012.282|pages=897‚Äì902|pmc=3746258}}</ref>
Researchers raise concerns about the impact of consent withdrawal (more easily facilitated by dynamic consent) on the integrity of their research data sets.
=== Rebuttals === There are a number of important limitations to consider when evaluating the results of studies of consent practices. In many cases, while a statistically significant preference for one form of consent over another can be found, this is not necessarily indicative of a clear majority preference. For example, Haddow et al., 2011, characterised their reported consent preferences as 'not strong'. Another study reported that while 58% of respondents described re-consent as 'a waste of time', 51% also felt that being asked for it was an indication that they were 'respected and involved' participants in research.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Master|first1=Zubin|last2=Claudio|first2=Jaime|last3=Rachul|first3=Christen|last4=Jean|first4=Wang|last5=Minden|first5=Mark|last6=Caulfield|first6=Timothy|title=Cancer patient perceptions on the ethical and legal issues related to biobanking|journal=BMC Medical Genomics|date=2013|volume=6|issue=8|doi=10.1186/1755-8794-6-8|url=http://bmcmedgenomics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1755-8794-6-8|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref>
In the case of prospective public attitude surveys on biobanking, of which there are many in the existing literature, Johnsson et al., 2010, found that reported willingness to share data and tissue for research was prone to both overestimating and underestimating recorded participation levels in different cases, leading to questions about the usefulness of this type of research in making predictions of future behaviours.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Johnsson|first1=Linus|last2=Helgesson|first2=Gert|last3=Rafnar|first3=Thorunn|last4=Halldorsdottir|first4=Ingibjorg|last5=Chia|first5=Kee-Seng|last6=Eriksson|first6=Stefan|last7=Hansson|first7=Mats G|title=Hypothetical and factual willingness to participate in biobank research|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|date=2010|volume=18|issue=11|page=1261|doi=10.1038/ejhg.2010.106|pmc=2987483|pmid=20648060}}</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=April 2011}}
[[File:EFMS.pdf|thumb|EFMS]] '''Energy and facility management software''' is a term used to refer to an enterprise-wide platform for handling technical data related to buildings and stems from the merger of [[Energy management software|EMS]] (energy management software), [[Computer-aided facility management|CAFM]] (Computer Aided Facility Management) and [[Energy accounting software|EAS]] (Energy Accounting Software). As such it involves the gathering and processing or information that is required for maintaining acceptable indoor comfort level while minimizing energy use.
==Purpose== An EFMS serves a dual purpose:
*'''Tactical:''' On a day-to-day operational level an EFMS will help improve comfort level where required while minimizing energy consumption. Should comfort level not be an issue, the EFMS will focus processes and resources on reducing energy spending. *'''Strategic:''' On a mid-to-long term scope an EFMS will support the development strategy of the organization with information that will support managerial decisions such as systems, vendors or processes efficiencies, ratings and critical areas etc.
== Method ==
=== Information Classes === To achieve its purpose an EFMS integrates several informational classes in a common processing environment, mainly:
*'''Energy consumption information''' information commonly handled by an EMS and derived from online metering devices (such as [[Electric energy meter|Energy meters]], [[Gas meter]]s). *'''System information''' such as [[HVAC|HVAC systems]] settings, sensor readings etc. commonly resident in a [[Building Management System|BMS]]. *'''Assets Information''', such as building size, floor number and area, cooling capacity of installed [[HVAC|HVAC systems]], maintenance logs etc. commonly found in a CAFM system. *'''Weather information''' commonly derived from internet weather feeds or locally installed sensors. *'''Occupancy / Use information''' such as room occupancy of a hotel or customers served at a retail store commonly found in an [[Enterprise resource planning|ERP]]. *'''Utility bills information''' commonly resident in an [[Energy accounting software|EAS]] (Energy Accounting Software).
=== Components === An EFMS should be consisted of at least the following modules:
*'''Visualization / Dashboard Module''' which will present graphical or table illustrations of energy information (from EMS), system information (from BMS) and Billing information (from EAS). *'''Alarming Module''' which will create and manage alarms based on given threshold values and / or Faults Detection & Diagnosis detection methods. *'''Work Order Module''' which will create and manage notifications of alarms directed towards appropriate users. The Work Order Module will manage actions of users related to each fault along the Fault Cycle (birth, detection, diagnosis, action, evaluation). *'''Data Sources Module''' which will manage the connection to and synchronization with the various data sources such as energy management systems and metering devices, [[Building Management System|BMS]], [[Energy accounting software|EAS]], [[Enterprise resource planning|ERP]] etc. *'''Reporting Module''' which will manage the creation and distribution of energy and facility reports.
=== Processes === The processes performed in an EFMS fall under the categories of: *'''Entry Processes''' which may be ''tactical'' such as the automated synchronization with a BMS or ERP or ''ad hoc'' such as the manual entry of utility bills data or the upload of a maintenance log. *'''FDD Processes''' (''Faults Detection & Diagnosis'') which may include sub-processes for setting various thresholds, selecting from a list of rules which ones should be applied to each specific building / installation and the tactical application of rule sets and threshold values to an FDD scanning process of building related data. *'''Work Order Processes''' which include processes for relaying alerts and faults to users and managing the actions they undertake until the issue is resolved. *'''Reporting Processes''' which involve tactical creation of visualization elements and reports or ad hoc querying processes for data mining and faults investigation.
==Applications== Applications of integrated EFMS suites will benefit mostly organizations with either very large and busy facilities, such as malls, hotel complexes and transportation hubs the complexity of which challenges operational efficiency and organizations with many buildings dispersed across remote locations such as retail chains, restaurant chains, banks and food store chains which operate medium-sized buildings that stretch [[facility management]] operations to high costs.
Commercial property managers that plan and manage energy efficiency projects generally use a software platform to perform energy audits and to collaborate with contractors to understand their full range of options. The [http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/buildings/tools_directory/software.cfm/ID=622/pagename=alpha_list_sub Department of Energy (DOE) Software Directory] describes EnergyActio software, a cloud based platform designed for this purpose.
==Notes== * [http://gregstanleyandassociates.com/whitepapers/FaultDiagnosis/Model-Based-Reasoning/model-based-reasoning.htm Model Based Reasoning for Faults Detection and Diagnosis] * [http://www.ashrae.gr/ANTONIADES_KALAITZIDIS.pdf Automated Continuous Commissioning for Energy Efficient Buildings] * [http://txspace.di.tamu.edu/handle/1969.1/5209 Enhancing Building Operations Through Automated Diagnostics: Field Test Results] * [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=535680 Real time recursive parameter estimation in energy management systems] * [http://www1.eere.energy.gov/femp/information/download_blcc.html Building Life-Cycle Cost (BLCC) Programs]

revision.text: '''"Esquisse d'un Programme"''' (Sketch of a Programme) is a famous proposal for long-term mathematical research made by the German-born, French mathematician [[Alexander Grothendieck]] in 1984.Scharlau, Winifred (September 2008), written at Oberwolfach, Germany, "Who is Alexander Grothendieck", ''Notices of the American Mathematical Society'' (Providence, RI: American Mathematical Society) 55(8): 930‚Äì941, {{issn|1088-9477}}, {{OCLC|34550461}}, http://www.ams.org/notices/200808/tx080800930p.pdf He pursued the sequence of logically linked ideas in his important project proposal from 1984 until 1988, but his proposed research continues to date to be of major interest in several branches of advanced mathematics. Grothendieck's vision provides inspiration today for several developments in mathematics such as the extension and generalization of [[Galois theory]], which is currently being extended based on his original proposal. ==Brief history== Submitted in 1984, the ''Esquisse d'un Programme''Alexander Grothendieck, 1984. "[http://webusers.imj-prg.fr/~leila.schneps/grothendieckcircle/EsquisseFr.pdf Esquisse d'un Programme]", (1984 manuscript), finally published in Schneps and Lochak (1997, I), pp.5-48; English transl., ibid., pp. 243-283. {{MR|1483107}}{{cite web|url=http://matematicas.unex.es/~navarro/res/esquisseeng.pdf|title=Sketch of a programme ''(English translation, hosted by the University of Extremadura)''|accessdate=October 28, 2012}} was a proposal submitted by Alexander Grothendieck for a position at the [[French National Centre for Scientific Research|Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique]]. The proposal was not successful, but Grothendieck obtained a special position where, while keeping his affiliation at the university of Montpellier, he was paid by the CNRS and released of his teaching obligations. Grothendieck held this position from 1984 till 1988.Rehmeyer, Julie (May 9, 2008), "Sensitivity to the Harmony of Things", ''Science News''Jackson, Allyn (November, 2004) "Comme Appel√© du N√©ant - As if summoned from the void: the life of Alexandre Grothendieck", Notices of the AMS This proposal was not formally published until 1997, because the author "could not be found, much less his permission requested".Schneps and Lochak (1997, I) p.1 The outlines of ''[[dessin d'enfant|dessins d'enfants]]'', or "children's drawings", and "[[Anabelian geometry]]", that are contained in this manuscript continue to inspire research; thus, "'''Anabelian geometry''' is a proposed theory in [[mathematics]], describing the way the [[algebraic fundamental group]] ''G'' of an [[algebraic variety]] ''V'', or some related geometric object, determines how ''V'' can be mapped into another geometric object ''W'', under the assumption that ''G'' is '''not''' an [[abelian group]], in the sense of being strongly [[noncommutative]]. The word ''anabelian'' (an [[alpha privative]] ''an-'' before ''abelian'') was introduced in ''Esquisse d'un Programme''. While the work of Grothendieck was for many years unpublished, and unavailable through the traditional formal scholarly channels, the formulation and predictions of the proposed theory received much attention, and some alterations, at the hands of a number of mathematicians. Those who have researched in this area have obtained some expected and related results, and in the 21st century the beginnings of such a theory started to be available."'' ==Abstract of Grothendieck's programme== ("''Sommaire''") *1. The Proposal and enterprise ("Envoi"). *2. "[[Oswald Teichm√ºller|Teichm√ºller]]'s Lego-game and the [[Galois group]] of Q over Q" ("Un jeu de ‚ÄúLego-Teichm√ºller‚Äù et le groupe de [[Galois]] de Q sur Q"). *3. [[Number fields]] associated with [[dessins d'enfant]]". ("Corps de nombres associ√©s √† un dessin d‚Äôenfant"). *4. [[Regular polyhedron|Regular polyhedra]] over [[finite field]]s ("Poly√®dres r√©guliers sur les corps finis"). *5. [[General topology]] or a '[[Moderated Topology]]' ("Haro sur la topologie dite 'g√©n√©rale', et r√©flexions heuristiques vers une topologie dite 'mod√©r√©e"). *6. [[Differentiable theories]] and [[moderated theories]] ("Th√©ories diff√©rentiables" (√† la Nash) et ‚Äúth√©ories mod√©r√©es"). *7. [[Pursuing Stacks]] ("√Ä la Poursuite des Champs").{{cite web |url=http://www.bangor.ac.uk/r.brown/pstacks.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722054515/http://www.bangor.ac.uk/r.brown/pstacks.htm |archivedate=2012-07-22 |df= }} *8. [[Two-dimensional geometry]] ("Digressions de g√©om√©trie bidimensionnelle").Cartier, Pierre (2001), "A mad day's work: from Grothendieck to Connes and Kontsevich The evolution of concepts of space and symmetry", ''Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.'' '''38'''(4): 389‚Äì408, . An English translation of Cartier (1998) *9. Summary of proposed studies ("Bilan d‚Äôune activit√© enseignante"). *10. Epilogue. *Notes Suggested further reading for the interested mathematical reader is provided in the ''References'' section. ===Extensions of Galois's theory for groups: Galois groupoids, categories and functors=== [[Galois]] has developed a powerful, fundamental [[algebraic theory]] in mathematics that provides very efficient computations for certain algebraic problems by utilizing the algebraic concept of [[Group (mathematics)|groups]], which is now known as the theory of [[Galois group]]s; such computations were not possible before, and also in many cases are much more effective than the 'direct' calculations without using groups.Cartier, Pierre (1998), "La Folle Journ√©e, de Grothendieck √† Connes et Kontsevich ‚Äî √âvolution des Notions d'Espace et de Sym√©trie", ''Les Relations entre les Math√©matiques et la Physique Th√©orique ‚Äî Festschrift for the 40th anniversary of the ''IH√âS'', Institut des Hautes √âtudes Scientifiques'', pp. 11‚Äì19 To begin with, Alexander Grothendieck stated in his proposal:'' "Thus, the group of Galois is realized as the [[automorphism group]] of a concrete, [[pro-finite group]] which respects certain structures that are essential to this group."'' This fundamental, Galois group theory in mathematics has been considerably expanded, at first to [[groupoids]]- as proposed in Alexander Grothendieck's ''Esquisse d' un Programme'' (''EdP'')- and now already partially carried out for groupoids; the latter are now further developed beyond groupoids to categories by several groups of mathematicians. Here, we shall focus only on the well-established and fully validated extensions of Galois' theory. Thus, EdP also proposed and anticipated, along previous Alexander Grothendieck's ''[[IH√âS]]'' seminars ([[SGA1]] to [[SGA4]]) held in the 1960s, the development of even more powerful extensions of the original Galois's theory for groups by utilizing categories, [[functors]] and [[natural transformations]], as well as further expansion of the manifold of ideas presented in Alexander Grothendieck's ''[[Descent theory|Descent Theory]]''. The notion of [[Motive (algebraic geometry)|motive]] has also been pursued actively. This was developed into the [[motivic Galois group]], [[Grothendieck topology]] and Grothendieck category .http://planetmath.org/encyclopedia/GrothendieckCategory.html Such developments were recently extended in [[algebraic topology]] ''via'' [[representable functor]]s and the [[fundamental groupoid functor]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Category theory|Mathematics}} * [[Grothendieck's Galois theory]] * [[Grothendieck's S√©minaire de g√©om√©trie alg√©brique]] * [[Anabelian geometry]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Related works by Alexander Grothendieck=== *[[Alexander Grothendieck]]. 1971, [[Rev√™tements √âtales]] et [[Groupe Fondamental]] ([[SGA1]]), chapter VI: ''[[Cat√©gories fibr√©es et descente]]'', Lecture Notes in Math. 224, Springer-Verlag: Berlin. *Alexander Grothendieck. 1957, Sur quelques points d'alg√®bre homologique,'' Tohoku Mathematics Journal'', '''9''', 119-221. *Alexander Grothendieck and [[Jean Dieudonn√©]].: 1960,'' [[√âl√©ments de g√©om√©trie alg√©brique]]''., Publ. ''[[IH√âS|Inst. des Hautes √âtudes Scientifiques]],'' ''([[IH√âS]])'', '''4'''. *Alexander Grothendieck et al.,1971. [[Grothendieck's S√©minaire de g√©om√©trie alg√©brique|S√©minaire de G√©om√©trie Alg√©brique du Bois-Marie]], Vol. 1-7, Berlin: Springer-Verlag. *Alexander Grothendieck. 1962. ''S√©minaires en G√©om√©trie Alg√©brique du Bois-Marie'', Vol. '''2''' - [[Cohomologie Locale des Faisceaux Coh√®rents]] et [[Th√©or√®mes de Lefschetz Locaux et Globaux]]., pp. 287. (''with an additional contributed expos√© by Mme. Michele Raynaud''). (Typewritten manuscript available in French; see also a brief summary in English References Cited: **[[Jean-Pierre Serre]]. 1964. [[Cohomologie Galoisienne]], Springer-Verlag: Berlin. **[[J. L. Verdier]]. 1965. [[Alg√®bre homologiques et Cat√©gories deriv√©es]]. [[North Holland Publ. Cie]]). *Alexander Grothendieck et al. S√©minaires en G√©ometrie Alg√®brique- 4, Tome 1, Expos√© 1 (or the Appendix to Expos√©e 1, by `[[N. Bourbaki]]) for more detail and a large number of results. [[AG4]] is freely available in French; also available is an extensive Abstract in English. *Alexander Grothendieck, 1984. [http://people.math.jussieu.fr/~leila/grothendieckcircle/EsquisseFr.pdf "Esquisse d'un Programme"], (1984 manuscript), finally published in "[[Geometric Galois Actions]]", L. Schneps, P. Lecture Notes'' '''242''', [[Cambridge University Press]], 1997, pp. 5-48; [http://matematicas.unex.es/~navarro/res/esquisseeng.pdf English transl.], ibid., pp. 243-283. {{MR|1483107}}. *Alexander Grothendieck, "[[La longue marche in √† travers la th√©orie de Galois.]]" = "The Long March Towards/Across the Theory of [[Galois]]", 1981 manuscript, [[University of Montpellier]] preprint series 1996, edited by J. Malgoire. ===Other related publications=== *{{citation|first=Leila|last=Schneps|authorlink=Leila Schneps|year=1994|title=The [[Grothendieck]] Theory of [[Dessin d'Enfant|Dessins d'Enfants]]|series=London Mathematical Society Lecture Note Series|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]}}. *{{Citation | editor1-last=Schneps | editor1-first=Leila | editor2-last=Lochak | editor2-first=Pierre | title=Geometric Galois Actions I: Around Grothendieck's Esquisse D'un Programme | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=London Mathematical Society Lecture Note Series | volume=242 | isbn=978-0-521-59642-8 | year=1997}} *{{Citation | editor1-last=Schneps | editor1-first=Leila | editor2-last=Lochak | editor2-first=Pierre | title=Geometric Galois Actions II: The Inverse Galois Problem, Moduli Spaces and Mapping Class Groups | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=London Mathematical Society Lecture Note Series | volume=243 | isbn=978-0-521-59641-1 | year=1997}} *{{citation|first1=David|last1=Harbater|first2=Leila|last2=Schneps|title=[[Fundamental group]]s of [[Moduli space|moduli]] and the [[Grothendieck‚ÄìTeichm√ºller group]]|journal=Trans. {{italic title}} [[File:Dictorum Factorumque Memorabilium Libri IX.jpg|thumb|1830 version of ''Facta et dicta memorabilia'']] '''''Factorum ac dictorum memorabilium libri IX''''' ("nine books of memorable deeds and sayings", also known as ''De factis dictisque memorabilibus'' or ''Facta et dicta memorabilia'') by [[Valerius Maximus]] (c. 20 BCE ‚Äì c. CE 50) was written around CE 30 or 31.<ref name="pagexiii">Walker, p. xiii</ref><ref name="columbia">[http://www.bartleby.com/65/va/Valerius.html ''The Columbia Encyclopedia'', Sixth Edition (2001-07), s.v. "Valerius Maximus"]</ref> It is a collection of approximately a thousand short stories that Valerius wrote during the reign of [[Tiberius]] (42 BCE ‚Äì CE 37).<ref name="pagexiii"/> The stories are a variety of anecdotes illustrating how the [[Ancient Rome|ancient Romans]] lived.<ref name="columbia"/> While the majority of the stories are of Roman life, he does have some foreign stories at the end of some chapters. Most of these are of [[Ancient Greece|Greek life]] and most of those are about [[Greek philosophy|Greek philosophers]] or famous kings.<ref>Walker, p. xix</ref>
Several of the stories relate to moral subjects that parallel those in the [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]]. Valerius refers to his moral stories as "examples" that were to be used as moral guidance.<ref name="pagexxii"/> Valerius' work on the preservation of moral values of the [[Roman Republic]] of the past was widely popular through the [[Age of Enlightenment]], a literary life-span of some 1,700 years. People read Valerius' work for practical guidance in their everyday tasks for living a moral life.<ref name="pagexxii">Walker, p. xxii</ref> This work was especially used as a reference by writers and professional [[Public speaking|orators]].<ref name="pagexiii"/><ref name="columbia"/>
It is estimated that Valerius's work on these nine books took over a decade.<ref name="rarely"/> He obtained material from [[Cicero]], and from [[Livy]], [[Sallust]], [[Gnaeus Pompeius Trogus|Pompeius Trogus]], [[Marcus Terentius Varro]] and other ancient historians.<ref name="rarely"/> Each of the nine books has several chapters. Each chapter is outlined and grouped [[theme (literature)|thematically]] and contains several stories illustrating that theme.<ref name="rarely"/><ref name="table">Walker, p. vii '''Table of Contents'''</ref> This work is the earliest known use of a [[hierarchical organization]] system for topics of a book.<ref>Princeton University Press article ''[http://press.princeton.edu/chapters/s8216.html A short history of information retrieval]''</ref> There are a total of 91 chapters covering a wide variety of subjects drawn from Roman life.<ref name="table"/> Valerius arranges his chapters focused on particular [[virtue]]s, moral and immoral habits, religious practices, superstitions and ancient traditions.<ref name="table"/> There is a thematic guide at the end of the work.<ref>Walker, p. 355</ref>
==Subjects==
===Omens=== One example of Valerius' balanced subject themes covered is where he writes stories about [[omen]]s.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> He notes that the observations of omens had a connection to [[religion in ancient Rome]] since many people of that time believed that omens were from divine providence.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> Valerius records that omens had played an important role when Rome had been demolished by the [[Gauls]] in 390 BCE. The [[Roman Senate|Senate]] was debating whether they should then move Rome to [[Veii]] or rebuild the city walls.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> While they were deciding some [[Cohort (military unit)|cohort]]s had just returned from guard duty.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> Their [[centurion]] then just happened to shout in the assembly place, "Standard-bearer, set up the standard; this is the best place for us to stay." The city was rebuilt in the same place then, since they interpreted these words as an omen.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref>
===Auspices=== One of the subject themes that Valerius wrote about was the [[superstition]] of [[auspices]] in Book 1 Chapter 4.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> Auspices means "bird observations." It is from the [[Latin]] words of ''avis'' (bird) and ''spicere'' (to sight or watch).<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> Before doing anything of great importance, the Romans would "take the auspices" in order to determine what the [[Roman mythology|gods]] approved.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> This was an examination of the behavior of birds in flight or eating.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> It was interpreted by an [[augur]] as to the will of the gods from this behavior.
A Roman story that Valerius writes about is the founding of Rome by [[Romulus and Remus]].<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> He records that the founding of the city was based on the auspices. Remus was the first to "take the auspices" by seeing six [[vulture]]s.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> Romulus later however saw twelve vultures. Romulus claimed he had a stronger claim because he saw a larger quantity, even though Remus was the first to spot vultures.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref>
Another "foreign" story Valerius writes on this theme for a comparison is on the founding of the city of [[Alexandria]] in [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]].<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> It was founded by [[Alexander the Great]] in 331 BCE. The [[architect]] was [[Deinocrates]].<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> He records that when Deinocrates was going to design a great city in Egypt, he had no chalk to use for writing.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> Instead he used a large quantity of [[barley]], and drew out the plans on the ground.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> A group of birds then came from a nearby lake and ate the barley.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> The Egyptian augur interpreted this to mean that there would be plenty of food for a large city there.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref>
===Modesty=== [[File:Marco Porcio Caton Major.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Cato the Elder]]]] Valerius writes on the theme of [[modesty]] in Book 4 Chapter 5 about the fact that there was no separate seating for the Conscript Fathers (Roman Senators) at the theater.<ref name="modesty1">Walker, p. 142, Book 4 Chapter 5.1 reads, ''From the foundation of our city to the consulship of Scipio Africanus and Tiberius Longus there was no separate seating for the Senate and the people when they watched the games. In spite of this, no member of the plebs ever brought himself to sit in front of the Conscript Fathers at the theater; the respect shown in our state was so scrupulous.''</ref> This was from the beginnings of Rome in the 8th century BCE until the time of the consulship of [[Scipio Africanus]] and [[Tiberius Sempronius Longus (consul 194 BCE)|Tiberius Sempronius Longus]] in 194 BCE.<ref name="modesty1"/> In spite of this no member of the [[pleb]]s ever sat in front of the Conscript Fathers.<ref name="modesty1"/> Their respect for this tradition was also shown when one day [[Lucius Quinctius Flamininus]] was to stand in the very back of the theater.<ref name="modesty1"/> He was placed there because he had been removed from the Roman Senate by [[Cato the Censor]] and [[Lucius Valerius Flaccus]]. Flamininus already held the office of [[Roman consul|consul]] and was the brother of [[Titus Flamininus]] (consul 192 BCE), who had defeated [[Philip V of Macedon]] in 197 BCE.<ref name="modesty1"/> In spite of this he still was forced to go to the back of the theater by Cato the Elder. Out of respect however, the entire audience moved Flamininus to the very front so that nobody was in front of him.<ref name="modesty1"/>
Valerius illustrates another story of modesty when he writes of [[Gaius Terentius Varro]].<ref name="modesty1"/> Varro devastated the Roman Republic when he started the [[Battle of Cannae]], one of the worst battles of recorded history. His sense of shame would not allow him to accept dictatorship, even though it was offered to him.<ref name="modesty1"/> The people of the Republic attributed the great loss to the anger of the gods. On the inscription under his death mask shows his good character which brought him more honor that most men receive from the dictatorship position itself.<ref name="modesty1"/>
Valerius records another story of modesty where king [[Hiero II of Syracuse]] hears of the disastrous defeat of the Romans at the [[Battle of Lake Trasimene]].<ref name="modesty2">Walker, p. 156</ref> He immediately sends as a gift to Rome 70,000 bushels of wheat, 50,000 bushels of barley, and 240 pounds of gold.<ref name="modesty2"/> So that the gold was accepted and not returned he presented it in the form of a statue of victory. This was so the Roman people would accept it on religious grounds.<ref name="modesty2"/>
===Parenting=== [[File:Halle CorneliaMotherOfTheCracchi.jpg|thumb|left|An 18th-century portrayal of [[Cornelia Africana|Cornelia]] proclaiming "These are my jewels," in reference to [[Gracchi|her sons]]]] Another example of Valerius' themes is where he writes stories about Roman parents and the affection they had toward their children. A story in Book 4 Chapter 4 on ''Poverty'' is about the [[Gracchus|Gracchus brothers]], [[Gaius Gracchus]] and his younger brother [[Tiberius Gracchus]]. The story relates how one day [[Cornelia Africana]], their mother (daughter of Publius Cornelius [[Scipio Africanus]]), was pestered by a lady guest that was showing off her elegant jewellery. Cornelia patiently endured this lady until her sons came home from school. Then, introducing them to this lady, she proclaimed proudly, "These are my jewels."<ref>Walker, p. 138</ref>
Another example in Book 8 Chapter 8 is about the philosopher [[Socrates]]. He writes of him showing an intimate side which did not distract from his stature because, as Valerius puts it, ''no part of wisdom was hidden from him.'' He tells how Socrates one time made a [[hobby horse|hobbyhorse]] out of [[Reed bed|reed]] for his sons. He would then play with the hobbyhorse with them showing Socrates' personal parental side.<ref>Walker, p. 291</ref>
Valerius writes many stories of other Roman fathers which generally are contrary to the stereotypical image of being brutal and harsh.<ref name=pagexv>Walker, p. xv</ref> Some of these examples are in Book 5 Chapter 7 titled ''The Love and Indulgence of Parents towards Their Children.''<ref>Walker, p. 189</ref> He writes that the real fathers are the ones that are benignly permissive and show indulgence.<ref name=pagexv/> He reports with delight that this kind of father could be found in the streets of Rome and that these fathers ''were as gentle as fathers in a comedy.''<ref>Walker, p. 193</ref> He does, however, describe in Book 5 Chapter 8 ''Fathers who were severe with their children'' some all-powerful Roman abusive fathers as being tyrannical [[patriarch]]s killing and murdering others including of their own blood. He clearly reports these that are extremely strict and severe as no longer in the role of being a loving father.<ref>Walker, p. 191</ref>
Valerius writes of [[Lucius Junius Brutus]], who killed his sons for failing in their military duties, ''He left the role of a father so that he could play the part of a [[Roman consul|consul]].''<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/5*.html#8.1 Book 5, Chapter 8.1]</ref> Other examples of these role changes can be found in Book 6. In Chapter 1.5 where Valerius tells the story of [[Quintus Fabius Maximus Eburnus]],<ref name="page19915">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.5, p. 199</ref> Eburnus had carried out the highest public offices with great splendor and finished off his career with much dignity; however, he had his son punished for a chastity that was dubious.<ref name="page19915"/> In Chapter 1.6 Valerius writes about Publius Atilius Philiscus who was abused as a child.<ref name="page19916">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.6, p. 199</ref> When he became an adult, Philiscus became a strict father on chastity.<ref name="page19916"/> Learning of his daughter's premarital sex, he murdered her.<ref name="page19916"/>
===The role of women=== {{See also|Women in Ancient Rome}} [[File:Tizian 094.jpg|thumb|[[Titian]]'s image of the rape of Lucretia]] Valerius writes of Roman women being generally in seclusion.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} He reports in Book 6 on ''Chastity'' the stereotypical woman as being well-behaved and who would rather face death than dishonor. One story is of [[Lucretia]] in Book 6 Chapter 1.1.<ref name="page198">Walker, p. 198</ref> He writes that she was violently forced to have sex with [[Sextus Tarquinius]], the son of King [[Tarquin the Proud]].<ref name="page198"/> Lucretia could not bear the disgrace and committed [[suicide]].<ref name="page198"/> Another example is about [[Hippo, a Greek woman]]. She committed suicide rather than being raped by drunken sailors.<ref>Valerius Maximus [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#ext.1 Book 6. ext. 1].</ref> Valerius even writes in Book 2, Chapter 6.14, of [[suttee]] being an admired practice model for all women to follow in his day.<ref name=pagexv/><ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/2*.html#6.14 Book 2 Chapter 6.14]</ref><ref name="pagexvi"/>
===Homosexuality=== {{See also|Homosexuality in ancient Rome}} Valerius writes about homosexuality, which was an unusual category for that time period of writers.<ref name="pagexvi">Walker, p. xvi</ref> This aspect of private life was kept under wraps.<ref name="pagexvi"/> The only relationship along these lines that was tolerated by law was that between a master and a slave.<ref name="pagexvi"/> Valerius, however, does report on male homosexuality in the [[Roman army]] and the [[upper class]].<ref name="pagexvi"/> He does not report on female homosexuality nor "[[gay women]]" as some writers did at the time.<ref name="pagexvi"/>
===Roman army=== In the stories of the Roman army, Valerius always records high-ranking military personnel taking advantage of their position. In Book 6 Chapter 1.10 Valerius tells the story of Gaius Cornelius.<ref name="page200110">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.10, p. 200</ref><ref name="bk6110">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#1.10 Book 6, Chapter 1.10]</ref> He was rewarded four times by his superiors to be the senior [[centurion]] of his [[Roman legion|legion]].<ref name="page200110"/> However Gaius Pescennius, a ''triumvir capitalis'' (prison manager) in CE 149, had Cornelius thrown in jail and shackled in irons for having sexual relations with a young boy of free birth.<ref name="page200110"/> Cornelius did not deny the charges and was prepared to make a ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#sponsio|sponsio]]'' (legal guarantee).<ref name="bk6110"/> In so doing, Cornelius was making a statement and putting down a sum of money as a guarantee of truth.<ref name="page200110"/> If the guaranteed statement was found to be false, the young boy was to be paid this amount.<ref name="page200110"/> His statement was to say that the boy openly and willingly sold his body for cash.<ref name="page200110"/><ref name="bk6110"/> The [[tribune]]s refused to allow this, since they thought soldiers of the Roman Republic should not make deals in which they could pay for pleasures at home by facing dangers overseas.<ref name="page200110"/> Cornelius spent the rest of his life in prison.<ref name="page200110"/><ref name="bk6110"/>
In Book 6 Chapter 1.11 Valerius tells the story of Marcus Laetorius Mergus.<ref name="page200111">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.11, p. 200</ref> Cominius and a tribune of the [[pleb]]s summoned Mergus, a high-ranking military career person, before the people because of sexual relations with young men and women outside his marriage. He was prosecuted and sent to prison.<ref name="page200111"/>
In Book 6 Chapter 1.12 Valerius tells the story of [[Chiomara]].<ref name="page202112">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1. ext. 2, p. 201</ref><ref name="bk6ext2">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#ext.2 Book 6, ext. 2]</ref> Chiomara was the wife of Ortiagon. During the [[Galatian War]] with Rome of 189 BC, [[Gnaeus Manlius Vulso]] was victorious in a campaign against the Galatian Gauls.<ref name="page202112"/> One of his centurions was put in charge of a group of captives including Chiomara. The centurion made sexual advances towards her and she rejected him.<ref name="page202112"/> Under violence and force he raped her. The centurion then offered, to assuage his shame, to ransom her back to her relatives.<ref name="page202112"/> When he received his ransom and was counting the gold pieces, Chiomara secretly indicated to her relatives to murder him and cut off his head.<ref name="bk6ext2"/> She later presented the head of the centurion to her husband.<ref name="page202112"/>
===Political views=== [[File:Lucius Appuleius Saturninus.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Coin of [[Lucius Appuleius Saturninus]]]] The political views of ordinary Romans basically were not written on by most ancient writers.<ref name="rarely">Walker, P. xvii</ref> Valerius, however, did write about the grassroots customs of Rome as a democratic society.<ref name="rarely"/> He points out that the poorer Romans had goals as to where they wanted to ultimately be and in what direction they wanted to go.<ref name="rarely"/>
One example of how political views were looked upon in his days is where he writes a story on [[Sextus Titus]], who kept a picture in his residence of a murdered [[Extremism|radical]] called [[Lucius Appuleius Saturninus]].<ref name="stitus">Walker, p. 271</ref><ref name="bk81damn3">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/8*.html#1.damn.3 Book 8, Chapter 8.1.damn.3]</ref> Titus was popular with the people because of a new land reform law he proposed; however, he was prosecuted and punished just because of the picture and his political views.<ref name="stitus"/><ref name="bk81damn3"/> He writes that the Romans felt a personal loyalty to the memory of these reformers. The tribal assembly of [[plebeian]]s felt that this memory could be led astray if there was an association to a radical.<ref name="rarely"/><ref name="stitus"/><ref name="bk81damn3"/>
Many times there were [[imposter]]s that said they were sons of populist leaders like [[Tiberius]], [[Gaius Marius]], [[Gracchus]], and [[Publius Clodius Pulcher]]. The people of Rome loved them.<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#7.1 Book 9, Chapter 7.1 and 7.2]</ref><ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#15.1 Book 9, Chapter 15. 1 -4]</ref> In fact, he records that one claimed to be the grandson of Gaius Marius and drew a crowd as what [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] himself would obtain.<ref name="rarely"/>
Valerius records the attitudes of the [[aristocracy]] and the contempt to which the [[Working class|lower class]] was subjected by the Roman elite. He demonstrates this with a story about [[Scipio Aemilianus Africanus]]. Scipio one day preached to a group of [[pleb]]s that basically they are nothing other than just a level above being slaves. He tells them they don't even deserve to call Italy their home.<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#2.3 Book 6, Chapter 6.2.3]</ref> Valerius shows a similar concept with [[Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica Serapio]]. The story goes that Nasica treated a poor man with ridicule and contempt because his hands were so rough from manual labor.<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/7*.html#5.2 Book 7 Chapter 5.2]</ref> Valerius writes of still another example where the aristocratic Claudia had hoped for more of the Roman common people to have been finished off in the [[First Punic War]].<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/8*.html#1.damn.4 Book 8, Chapter 1.damn.4]</ref>
[[File:EumenesII.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Coin of [[Eumenes II]]]]
===Generosity=== Valerius gives examples of generosity in Book 5 Chapter 8.<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref> Valerius writes that generosity is given to those that are poor.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> The Latin word for generosity is ''liberalitas''. The god of wine is Liber. The god Liber and the word ''liberalitas'' come from the word ''liber'', meaning "free." Here he tells the story of how, after the Romans captured Asia from King [[Antiochus III the Great]] in 190 BCE, they gave a large portion of it to their ally King [[Eumenes II]] of [[Pergamum]] free as a permanent gift.<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref>
Another example of generosity which Valerius writes about occurs after the Romans had defeated [[Philip V of Macedonia]]. In 196 BCE, the Greeks had the [[Isthmian Games]]. Here [[Titus Quinctius Flamininus]] proclaimed the independence of the Greek states from [[Macedon]]ian rule.<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref> At the games, the stadium was full of people and Titus had the herald make the following proclamation: "The Roman people and Senate, and Titus Quinctius Flamininus, their general, having vanquished the Macedonians and Philip, their king, order that Greece shall be free from foreign garrisons, not subject to tribute, and shall live under her own customs and laws."<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref>
===Kindness and compassion=== The themes in Chapter 1 of Book 5 are [[kindness]] and [[compassion]]; Valerius gives several examples based on these concepts.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> He considered these lesser [[virtue]]s than [[generosity]], although companions of it.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> Valerius writes that kindness is shown to those that are in trouble and compassion is for those whose luck has turned against them.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> He considered generosity to be the one that derived its name from a god, and should receive the most approval of these three.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
One Roman story is where Valerius gives an example of generosity, kindness and compassion. Here he explains that one day the [[Roman Senate]] was offered a large sum of ransom money for the release of 2,743 Carthaginian soldiers and refused it. The Senate released the soldiers to the representatives that had come to get them, and forgave the crimes. The representatives were astonished and even admitted that they themselves would not have been so kind and generous.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
Another Roman story in which Valerius writes about kindness is where king [[Syphax]] of western Numidia died in prison in Tibur (modern day [[Tivoli, Italy]]) in 201 BCE. The Senate gave him a state funeral with a proper burial.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
Another similar Roman story in which Valerius writes about compassion is where the Senate sent a [[quaestor]] to Alba (in [[Latium]]) in 167 BCE. There King [[Perseus]] of [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]] was banished to and had just died there. They wanted to give him honor and provided a state funeral for the king.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
[[File:Forum romanum 1880.jpg|thumb|[[Roman Forum]]]]
===Gratitude=== Valerius gives examples of gratitude in Book 5 Chapter 2 as the theme.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> One example is when Valerius writes about how [[Capua]] was being besieged by [[Quintus Fulvius Flaccus]] at the [[first Battle of Capua]]; there were two Campanian women who had kind feelings for Rome. They devoted much of their time and property to its benefit.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> One was Vestia Oppia, a married woman with a family, who labored everyday for the Roman army.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> Another was Cluvia Facula, a prostitute, who supplied food to the Roman [[prisoners of war]].<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> When Capua was defeated, the Roman Senate gave back their freedom and property and rewarded them. These two momen were even praised at an important Senate meeting in 210 BCE.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref>
Valerius gives another example of gratitude when he writes of [[Quintus Fabius Maximus Verrucosus]] (c. 280 BC ‚Äì 203 BC), called '''Cunctator''' (''the Delayer'').<ref name="grat2">Walker, p. 166</ref> Fabius died in 203 BCE after being [[Roman consul|consul]] for five terms. Many people of Rome generously gave money to his funeral in gratitude for his leadership.<ref name="grat2">Walker, p. 166</ref> When he was still alive, to show gratitude of his outstanding service to the Roman people, a [[referendum]] of the [[pleb]]s gave equal power to his [[magister equitum]] [[Marcus Minucius Rufus (consul 221 BC)|Marcus Minucius Rufus]] as co-dictator in 217 BCE.<ref name="grat2">Walker, p. 166</ref>
[[File:Carthage location 2.png|thumb|left|[[Carthage]] location]]
===Ingratitude=== Valerius gives as the theme "ingratitude" in Book 4 Chapter 3. Valerius writes that [[Scipio Aemilianus]], grandson of famous general [[Scipio Africanus]], had destroyed two major cities, [[Numantia]] and [[Carthage]], that were major threats to Rome. However, in Rome later, he met his death in mysterious circumstances in 129 BCE.<ref name="myster">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/4*.html#1.12 Book 4, Chapter 1.12]</ref> There was never anyone in the [[Roman Forum]] that avenged his death.<ref name="myster"/>
Valerius writes of another example on ingratitude being the circumstances around [[Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica Serapio]]. Nasica had led a group of conservative senators of the Roman Senate to kill the populist tribune of the plebs [[Tiberius Gracchus]] in 133 BCE.<ref name="merit">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/3*.html#2.17 Book 3, Chapter 2.17]</ref> He soon afterward had to withdraw from public life because the people of Rome had judged his merits unfairly.<ref name="merit"/> Nasica, a [[Pontifex Maximus]], went to [[Pergamum]] ostensibly as a [[diplomat]] and never returned.<ref name="merit"/> He died there, but never missed his country because the Roman people were so ungrateful for what he considered a great deed he had done for them.<ref name="merit"/>
[[File:Gaius Gracchus Tribune of the People.jpg|thumb|right|The [[rostra]] at the Roman Forum]]
===Infamous crimes=== On another theme, Valerius writes of several examples of infamous crimes in Book 8 Chapter 1 and how they related to [[jealousy]].<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref>
One example Valerius records of acquittal ''(absoluti)'' is where Marcus Horatius is found guilty by King [[Tullus Hostilius]] of killing his sister.<ref name="abs811">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/8*.html#1.abs.1 Book 8 Chapter 1.abs.1]</ref> Horatius was acquitted of the crime when he appealed to the public.<ref name="abs811"/> The brutal nature of the killing influenced King Tullus to convict him; however, the motive for which Horatius did it influenced the people.<ref name="abs811"/> In a battle defending Rome Horatius defeated the Curiatius brothers and killed them. His sister was in love with one of these brothers and planned on marrying him.<ref name="abs811"/> She wept over him, hearing of his death. Horatius murdered her then because of her premature love affair with the enemy.<ref name="abs811"/> The people of Rome felt this was harsh punishment rather than an actual crime of the Roman Republic. Horatius received glory for not only killing the Curiatius brothers, the enemy, but for killing his sister.<ref name="abs811"/> In this case the Roman people were acting as a strict guardian of chastity.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref>
Another case Valerius records is where the Roman people were acting as an unfair, lax judge. In this case [[Servius Sulpicius Galba (consul 144 BC)|Servius Sulpicius Galba]] was being harshly denounced at the [[rostra]] by [[Lucius Scribonius Libo]], tribune of the plebs in 149 BCE.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref> [[Cato the Elder]] supported the tribune's charges in a grand speech at a [[Roman assemblies|Roman assembly]] as is recorded in his ''Origins''.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref> Galba had committed an atrocious [[war crime]] against the [[Lusitanians]]. He had made a peace agreement with the Lusitanians, but then massacred 8,000 of them while he was governor of [[Hispania|Spain]] in 150 BCE.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref> Galba, being a great speaker in his own right, had no real defense for his crimes. Through bribery and bringing forth his children and the orphan child of a relative before the public in a speech for mercy, he procured his acquittal.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref>
Another case where Valerius records ancient history crimes is about Gaius Cosconius, [[praetor]] in 89 BCE and governor of [[Illyria]] from 78 to 76 BCE.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref> He was accused of misgovernment under the [[Servilian Law]] passed in 101 BCE.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref> There was no doubt that he was guilty; however, he recited a poem about his accuser, Valerius Valentinus, and got an acquittal.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref> The poem was about how Valerius seduced a young man in a striped [[toga]] and a young freeborn woman. Valerius was then convicted by the acquittal of Cosconius.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref>
===Outrageous behavior=== Valerius reports in Book 9 Chapter 5 under Foreign Stories that [[Alexander the Great]] had three stages of arrogance.<ref name="alex">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#5.ext.1 Book 9 Chapter 5.ext.1]</ref> One was that he looked down on his father [[Philip II of Macedon]] and claimed that Jupiter Hammon was his real father.<ref name="alex"/> Another was that he took up the ways of the [[Persian people]] by dressing and behaving their way.<ref name="alex"/> Still another was that Alexander believed himself to be a god, not a human being.<ref name="alex"/>
Valerius writes another foreign story here of [[Xerxes I of Persia]].<ref name="xerxes">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#5.ext.2 Book 9 Chapter 5.ext.2]</ref> To show his outrageous behavior and arrogance, he tells how Xerxes summoned all the leaders of Asia together.<ref name="xerxes"/> Just as he was about to declare war on Greece, he tells them, ''I did not want people to think that I was acting on my own initiative, so I brought you together here. But remember that it is your duty to obey me rather than persuade me.''<ref name="xerxes"/> Valerius reports that in the invasion, Xerxes suffered such a defeat that one would wonder if his words were just arrogance or stupidity.<ref name="xerxes"/>
Valerius writes on still another foreign story of [[Hannibal]] and how arrogant he was after his success at the [[Battle of Cannae]].<ref name="hannibal">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#5.ext.3 Book 9 Chapter 5.ext.3]</ref> He tells how Hannibal had [[delusions of grandeur]] and would not then receive any of his fellow citizens directly. He would only communicate through a go-between.<ref name="hannibal"/> He even insulted his cavalry commander Maharbal, who had said in front of his tent in a loud voice that he had planned things so that Hannibal would be dining on the Capitol in Rome within a few days.<ref name="hannibal"/>
==Other topics== Some other subjects that Valerius wrote about included: *Bravery *Cruelty *Dreams *Fidelity *Friendship *Innate characteristics *Moderation *Modesty *Omens *Parental Love *Physical resemblance *Prestige *Revenge *Superstitious cults *Women lawyers
