[[File:Cup or faces paradox.svg|thumb|Profiles/vase]] [[File:Man and crane, Mangas-Mimbres pot.jpg|thumb|Man and crane, [[Mimbres culture]] pot, c. 1000 -1150 AD]] '''Figure‚Äìground organization''' is a type of perceptual grouping which is a vital necessity for recognizing objects through vision. In [[Gestalt psychology]] it is known as identifying a ''figure'' from the back''ground''. For example, you see words on a printed paper as the "figure" and the white sheet as the "background".<ref>Schacter, Daniel L., Daniel T. Gilbert, and Daniel M. Wegner. "Chapter 4: Sensation and Perception, Vision II: Recognizing What We Perceive." Psychology. ; Second Edition. N.p.: Worth, Incorporated, 2011. 149-50. Print.</ref>
==Examples== The most famous example of figure‚Äìground perception is probably the [[Rubin vase|faces‚Äìvase drawing that Danish psychologist Edgar Rubin described]].<ref>Rubin, E. (1921) ''Visuell Wahrgenommene Figuren : Studien in psychologischer Analyse''. Kobenhaven: Gyldendalske boghandel.</ref><ref>Rubin, E. (2001). Figure and Ground. In Yantis, S.(Ed.), ''Visual Perception''. (pp. 225-229). Philadelphia, Psychology Press</ref> This drawing exemplifies one of the key aspects of figure‚Äìground organization, edge-assignment and its effect on shape perception. Notice in the faces/vase drawing, the perceived shape depends critically on the direction in which the border (edge) between the black and white regions is assigned. If the two curvy edges between the black and white regions are assigned inward then the central white region is seen as a vase shape in front of a black background. No faces are perceived in this case. On the other hand, if the edges are assigned outwards, then the two black profile faces are perceived on a white background and no vase shape is perceived. The human visual system will then settle on either of the interpretations of the Rubin vase and alternate between them. Functional brain imaging shows that when people see the Rubin image as a face, there is activity in the temporal lobe, specifically in the face-selective region <ref>Schacter, L.D., Gilbert, D.T., Wegner, D.M. (2011). "Psychology (2nd ed.)." New York, NY: Worth Publishers</ref><ref>Hasson, U., Hendler, T., Ben Bashat, D., and Malach, R. (2001). Vase or face? A neural correlate of shape-selective grouping processes in the human brain. J. Cogn. Neurosci. 13, 744‚Äì753.</ref>
==Perceptual process== How does the brain decide in a visual scene which item is the figure and which are part of the ground? This perceptual decision can be based on many cues, all of which are of a probabilistic nature. For instance, size helps us distinguish between the figure and the ground, since smaller regions are often (but not always) figures. Object shape can help us distinguish figure from ground, because figures tend to be convex. Movement also helps; the figure may be moving against a static environment. Color is also a cue, because the background tends to continue as one color behind potentially multiple foreground figures, whose colors may vary. Edge assignment also helps; if the edge belongs to the figure, it defines the shape while the background exists behind the shape. But it's at times difficult to distinguish between the two because the edge that would separate figure from ground is really part of neither, it equally defines both the figure and the background.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Schacter | first1 = Daniel L. | first2 = Gilbert | last2 = Daniel T. | first3 = Wegner | last3 = Daniel M. | title = [[Psychology: Second Edition]] | location = United States of America | publisher = [[Worth Publishers]] |date=March 2011 | pages = 149
| isbn = 1-4292-3719-8 }}</ref>
Evidently, the process of distinguishing figure from ground (sometimes called figure‚Äìground segmentation) is inherently probabilistic, and the best that the brain can do is to take all relevant cues into account in order to generate a probabilistic best-guess. In this light, [[Bayesian approaches to brain function|Bayesian]] figure‚Äìground segmentation models have been proposed to simulate the probabilistic inference by which the brain may distinguish figure from ground.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Goldreich|first=D|author2=Peterson, MA|title=A Bayesian observer replicates convexity context effects in figure‚Äìground perception.|journal=Seeing and perceiving|year=2012|volume=25|issue=3-4|pages=365‚Äì95|pmid=22564398|doi=10.1163/187847612X634445}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Barghout|first=L|author2=Lee, L|title=Perceptual information processing system.|journal=USPatent Patent Application 10/618,543,|year=2003}}</ref>
==Artistic applications== Figure‚Äìground organization is used to help artists and designers in composition of a 2D piece. Figure‚Äìground reversal may be used as an intentional [[visual design]] technique in which an existing image's foreground and background colors are purposely swapped to create new images.
==Non-visual== Figure‚Äìground perception can be expanded from visual perception to include abstract (i.e. non-visual) concepts such as melody/harmony, subject/background and positive/negative space.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=October 2016}} The concept of figure and ground fully depends on the observer and not on the item itself.<ref name="figure and ground">{{cite book |last=Carlson |first=Neil R |title=Psychology the science of behaviour-figure and ground |year=2010 |publisher=Pearson Canada |location=USA |isbn=978-0-205-64524-4 |pages=175}}</ref>
==Types of figure‚Äìground problems== [[File:Star-jeans.jpg|thumb|Type 2: The actual ground is the figure.]] There are three types of figure‚Äìground problems: #The figure and the ground compete. #The figure should be the ground and the ground should be the figure. #The figure and ground create an [[optical illusion]].<ref>Lohr L. Creating Graphics for Learning and Performance: Lessons in Visual Literacy Cleveland, OH: Prentice-Hall, 2007.</ref>

'''Francisc Iosif Rainer''' (December 28, 1874 ‚Äì August 4, 1944) was an [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]]-born [[Romania]]n pathologist, physiologist and anthropologist. From an immigrant family, he earned early recognition for his experimental work in anatomy, and helped reform Romanian medical science. He spent much of his youth training himself in [[anatomical pathology]] and the various areas of [[natural science]], gaining direct experience as a microbiologist, surgeon, and military physician. With teaching positions at the [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza University|University of Ia»ôi]] and the [[University of Bucharest]], where he established specialized sections, Rainer became a noted promoter of science and an innovator in his field. He notably favored and introduced the anatomical study of "functional structures", and was in particular preoccupied with issues pertaining to [[ontogenesis]] and [[kinesiology]]. An intellectual influence on several generations of doctors, his wife was [[Marta Trancu-Rainer]], Romania's first female surgeon.
In addition to his experimental approach, Rainer is remembered as a talented pedagogue and public speaker, who took public stances in defense of his social and cultural ideals. Vilified by the far-right for his left-wing stances, he blended [[progressivism]] with [[genetic determinism]], and, although an adept of [[eugenics]], condemned [[scientific racism]]. He was notably involved with [[Dimitrie Gusti]]'s project of [[rural sociology]], contributing an anthropological record of several isolated villages on the [[Carpathians|Carpathian]] slopes. During his lifetime, Rainer also set up a large collection of craniums and skeletons, which became the centerpiece of his Bucharest anthropology department.
==Biography==
===Early life=== Francisc Rainer was a native of [[Sadhora|Rohozna]] town, near [[Chernivtsi|Czernowitz]], in [[Crown land|Austrian-ruled]] [[Bukovina]]. His parents were [[Lutheran]], but baptized their son [[Roman Catholic]].<ref name="z155">Zamfirescu, p.155</ref> His father, Gustav Adolf Ignatz Rainer, emigrated to the [[Romanian Old Kingdom]] as an employee of the [[Bethel Henry Strousberg|Strousberg Company]] that built the [[Bucharest]]-[[Giurgiu]] railway, the country's first. Remaining there, he obtained a post in the administration of the [[CƒÉile Ferate Rom√¢ne|national railroad company]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.21‚Äì22; Zamfirescu, p.155</ref> His mother Maria (or Ana) came from a clerical family,<ref name="z155"/> and was a housewife.<ref name="r&c22">Riga & CƒÉlin, p.22</ref> The boy received his primary education at home from his parents, later attending [[Saint Sava National College]] in Bucharest. Among the teachers who were particularly helpful was [[Sabba »òtefƒÉnescu]] in natural sciences.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.23‚Äì24; Zamfirescu, p.155</ref> Rainer read extensively, teaching himself [[Latin]] and [[Ancient Greek]], and becoming passionate about the literary works of [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] and the philosophy of [[Arthur Schopenhauer]]. He slowly discarded the latter's influence when he discovered [[Heraclitus]], [[Ernst Haeckel]], and classical [[Materialism|materialistic]] thought.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.16‚Äì18, 22‚Äì26, 40, 121</ref> Such works diverted him from his original goal of becoming a [[Catholic missions|Catholic missionary]].<ref name="r&c22"/>
In 1892, he enrolled in the medical faculty of the University of Bucharest. While still a student, Rainer was given important tasks by a professor in his [[histology|histological]] laboratory. In 1896, he was named a junior teaching assistant in the medical clinic at [[Col»õea Hospital]]; he remained there for nearly two decades.<ref>Majuru, pp.281‚Äì282; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.24, 28‚Äì32, 177; Zamfirescu, p.155</ref> During this time, troubled by "the great issues of the Cosmos", he imposed on himself a rigorous program of study and exercise (including cycling, mountaineering and [[fencing]]).<ref name="amaj282">Majuru, p.282</ref> Although struggling to make ends meet, Rainer deepened his anatomical research, closely studying human morphology, and experimented with examination techniques during [[Autopsy|autopsies]], founding a Romanian Anatomical Society for the purpose of sharing results.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.29‚Äì32, 38‚Äì39, 137</ref> He also attended [[Anghel Saligny]]'s lectures in chemistry at the [[Politehnica University of Bucharest|School of Bridges]], worked as a chemist in [[Constantin Istrati]]'s lab, then as a pathologist at the [[University of Agronomic Sciences and Veterinary Medicine|Veterinary School]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.33, 35</ref> He moved between Col»õea, [[Filaret Hospital|Filaret]] and the school of assistant surgeons, taking part in the campaign against [[tuberculosis]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.36, 177</ref> In the summers of 1900 and 1901, he took part in an anti-[[cholera]] campaign in the [[Danube Delta]], which also allowed him to study the native flora and fauna.<ref>H√Ænganu, p.158; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.35</ref>
He completed his doctorate in 1903, the topic being a particular form of [[cirrhosis]]. Having performed numerous autopsies at the hospital, he made an original discovery himself; at the end of the thesis committee's debate, two of its members, Dr. Stoicescu from Col»õea and [[Victor Babe»ô]], extended their collegial greetings to Rainer.<ref name="z155"/> Aside from this pair, his professors included [[Alexandru Obregia]], [[Nicolae Kalinderu]], [[Thoma Ionescu]], [[Gheorghe Marinescu]], [[Ioan Cantacuzino]] and [[Mina Minovici]].<ref>H√Ænganu, p.157; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.24, 26‚Äì28, 35, 38‚Äì39</ref> Also in 1903, Rainer, recently [[Romanian nationality law|naturalized Romanian]], married [[Marta Trancu-Rainer|Marta Trancu]], an [[Armenians in Romania|Armenian Romanian]] doctor who had worked with him at Col»õea.<ref name="anmarta1">{{ro icon}} Ana√Øs Nersesian, [http://www.araratonline.com/PDF/Ararat/2006/Ararat%2002-2006.pdf "O personalitate a medicinei rom√¢ne»ôti. Doctor Marta Trancu Rainer (1)"], in ''Ararat'', n.2/2006, p.4</ref> They had corresponded intensely on scientific and cultural subjects, before becoming romantically involved.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.32‚Äì34</ref> After completing her studies, Marta became Romania's first female surgeon.<ref>[[Nicolae Iorga]], ''Coresponden»õƒÉ'', vol.3, p.143. [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1991, {{ISBN|978-973210-168-1}}; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.31‚Äì34, 35‚Äì36</ref> Their only child, daughter Sofia, was born on in May 1904.<ref name="anmarta1"/><ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.35‚Äì36</ref>
[[File:N. Minovici »ôi Rainer, necropsie, ca. 1900.jpg|thumb|380px|Intern Rainer (in dark suit, perched) witnessing an [[autopsy]] performed by [[Nicolae Minovici]], ''ca.'' 1900]] During that period, Rainer made two visits to [[German Empire|Germany]]. The first, in 1906, involved work at [[Berlin]]'s [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Frederick William University]] in the laboratories of [[Fedor Krause]] and [[Oscar Hertwig]], as well as a study of [[embryology]] and [[comparative anatomy]]. His animal experiments there were primarily focused on the [[ossification]] process. At the anatomical institute led by [[Heinrich Wilhelm Gottfried von Waldeyer-Hartz|Heinrich Wilhelm Waldeyer]], he analyzed the brains of individuals belonging to different races.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.37‚Äì38, 107, 109; H√Ænganu, p.158</ref> The second visit, in 1911, involved a stop at the [[German Hygiene Museum]] in [[Dresden]], at the anatomy institute of the [[University of Jena]] and at [[Leipzig]]. Near the trip's conclusion, while in [[Weimar]], he visited [[Goethe House (Weimar)|Goethe's House]].<ref>H√Ænganu, p.158; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.39‚Äì40</ref>
===Ia»ôi career and World War I=== Upon his return in 1912, Rainer became assistant professor at Bucharest.<ref name="z155"/> The following year, with referrals from [[Constantin Ion Parhon]],<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.46</ref> he became chairman of the anatomy department at the University of Ia»ôi medical faculty. Soon after his appointment, with the outbreak of the [[Second Balkan War]], he was mobilized in the [[Romanian Land Forces]] medical service. He barely escaped with his life when his automobile fell off the [[pontoon bridge]] at [[Nikopol, Bulgaria|Nikopol]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.47</ref> Upon his return, he busied himself with organizing his Ia»ôi department, supplying the microscopes, microtomes, thermostats, magazine collections and a projector for the faculty.<ref>H√Ænganu, p.158; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.47</ref> Meanwhile, during this period, he was involved in scientific publication, sitting on the editorial board of ''Spitalul'', writing for ''Romania MedicalƒÉ'' and, in 1911, helping found the Paris-based ''Annales de Biologie''.<ref>H√Ænganu, p.158; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.39</ref>
According to Marta Rainer's own account, her husband's move to Ia»ôi at age forty marked the end of a "prolonged adolescence", settling Rainer on the path to professional success.<ref>Majuru, p.281</ref> As Rainer himself noted, teaching was a major responsibility: "I have always held the belief that there is no feeling so great, no thought so vast and deep, that they may not reach out to young minds and hearts."<ref>Majuru, p.281; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.93</ref> He set for himself the goal of answering to some of "the great issues of mankind", with "a prolonged action to strengthen my spirit."<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.47‚Äì48</ref> In his university lectures, Rainer taught that the purpose of medical science was human progress, "that we may always reach for something that is set higher".<ref>Vitner, p.104</ref> He also held that "each of us owes more to society than society owes us."<ref>Majuru, p.288; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.90‚Äì91</ref>
While in Ia»ôi, Rainer joined the left-wing literary circle formed around ''[[Via»õa Rom√¢neascƒÉ]]'' magazine, for which he contributed notes on medical science.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.62‚Äì63</ref> He befriended the group's doyen, [[Garabet IbrƒÉileanu]], whom he treated for his lung problems. Rainer persuaded IbrƒÉileanu, who was Marta's cousin,<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.60‚Äì61</ref> to hold courses in Romanian language and literature two evenings a week for medical students. His intention was to develop cultured doctors, and the students heard lectures by [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], [[George Top√Ærceanu]] and [[Titu Maiorescu]].<ref>H√Ænganu, p.158; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.61‚Äì62</ref> He also took them for nature excursions so they could observe biological phenomena outside the laboratory.<ref name="h158">H√Ænganu, p.158</ref> Rainer himself traveled extensively after 1914: among his earliest trips was a working visit to [[Od√≥n de Buen y del Cos|Od√≥n de Buen]]'s oceanographic institute in [[Palma, Majorca|Palma de Mallorca]].<ref>H√Ænganu, p.158; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.64</ref>
In 1916, following Romania's entry into [[World War I]], Rainer returned to Bucharest and rejoined Marta, being called up for medical service as a Colonel.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.67</ref> During the [[Romania during World War I|1916 counteroffensive]], the Rainers set up surgery wards in the hospitals that had become full to overflowing with wounded from the [[Battle of Turtucaia]] and the [[zeppelin]] attack on Bucharest.<ref>H√Ænganu, pp.158‚Äì159; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.65‚Äì67</ref> Later, during Bucharest's occupation by the [[Central Powers]], Francisc Rainer established temporary hospitals in schools. He continued teaching under the German administration, so that his students would not miss a year, but was also obliged to teach separate courses for German students. He managed to prevent the occupying authorities from requisitioning the faculty's possessions.<ref>H√Ænganu, pp.158‚Äì159; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.68‚Äì70</ref> Viewed as political suspects, the Rainers were singled out for [[internment]] in [[Kingdom of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]], but spared by Minovici's intervention on his behalf.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.69, 72</ref> Marta Rainer, who managed war hospitals, organized teams of surgeons to help deal with the humanitarian crisis, and operated non-stop during the extremely cold winter of 1917‚Äì1918.<ref name="anmarta3">{{ro icon}} Ana√Øs Nersesian, [http://www.araratonline.com/PDF/Ararat/2006/Ararat%2004-2006.pdf "O personalitate a medicinei rom√¢ne»ôti. Doctor Marta Trancu Rainer (3)"], in ''Ararat'', n.4/2006, p.6</ref>
Following [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|Romania's withdrawal from the war]], Rainer resumed his contacts with Romanian physicians stranded on unoccupied territory. His wartime work in experimental surgery attracted young men and women, including some of his former students at Ia»ôi. They included [[Grigore T. Popa]], who was selected for Rainer's permanent team during 1918.<ref>H√Ænganu, p.159; Popa, p.230; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.69‚Äì70</ref> Other early members were Florica CernƒÉtescu (Popa's fianc√©e) and Ilie Th. Riga.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.69‚Äì70, 180</ref> By late 1918, Rainer was conceiving of an education reform, aiming to compress theoretical aspects and "routine" work while providing students with as much laboratory experience as possible. His ideas were received with skepticism by the physiologist [[Ioan Athanasiu]], who stood for the classical approach.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.111‚Äì113</ref>
For a while in 1919, Rainer made a return to teaching in Ia»ôi, where he also resumed his activity in the fight against tuberculosis.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.72‚Äì75</ref> After the [[First Armistice at Compi√®gne|Armistice of November]] signaled a worldwide return to peace, Rainer had to fend off allegations and angry students demonstrations, with allegations that he had been a turncoat and a collaborator of the Germans. During 1919, a commission of inquiry cleared his name, noting that he had displayed "absolute loyalty" to the legitimate Romanian government.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.70‚Äì71</ref> He himself vouched for his colleague [[Ecaterina Arbore]], arrested for her revolutionary socialist militancy.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.73</ref> After the [[1920 Romanian general strike|general strike of 1920]] was broken up by the authorities, Rainer was part of the investigative commission which determined that the labor organizer [[Her»ôcu Aroneanu]] had been beaten to death.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.74‚Äì75</ref>
===Bucharest school of anatomy creation=== [[File:Rainer cu vertebre, 1926.jpg|thumb|270px|Rainer in his lab, with a specimen of [[cervical vertebrae]] (1926)]] In 1920, Rainer was employed by the new anatomy and embryology department set up at Bucharest University. Afflicted by deafness, attributed to his long-term exposure to [[formaldehyde]], he continued to work at the same pace, but was noticeably withdrawn from public life.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.19‚Äì20</ref> The anatomy section existed only in name when Rainer took over. Rainer took personal charge of furnishing it, in the end setting up a large collection of craniums and full skeletons that earned the respect of Western colleagues such as [[Eug√®ne Pittard]],<ref>Bucur, p.78</ref> [[Carleton S. Coon]], [[Henri Victor Vallois]], and [[Kurt Warnekros]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.85‚Äì86, 150‚Äì151</ref> He was seconded by his devoted disciple and godson, the endocrinologist [[»òtefan Milcu]] (he eventually left Rainer's team in 1932, after developing an allergy to formaldehyde).<ref>BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, pp.11‚Äì12, 13</ref> Other important presences among Rainer's students and collaborators were [[George Emil Palade]]<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.19, 186</ref><ref name="mnbnegru">{{ro icon}} Mihai Neagu Basarab, [http://www.viata-medicala.ro/Dr.-Natalia-Neagu.html*articleID_6341-dArt.html "Dr. Natalia Neagu"], in ''Via»õa MedicalƒÉ'', n.3/2013</ref> and [[VintilƒÉ Cioc√¢lteu]],<ref>{{ro icon}} C. D. Zeletin, [http://www.romlit.ro/vintil_cioclteu "VintilƒÉ Cioc√¢lteu"], in ''[[Rom√¢nia LiterarƒÉ]]'', n.6/2002</ref> distinguished for their work in the United States. At various intervals, the team also included surgeon [[Ion »öurai]], pharmacologist [[Alfred Teitel]], embryologist [[Benedict M. Menke»ô]], and anatomist [[Zalman Iagnov]].<ref name="mnbnegru"/><ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.19, 129‚Äì130, 185‚Äì186; {{ro icon}} Francisc Schneider, [http://www.jewishfed.ro/downloads/realitatea/RE360-361.pdf "EvocƒÉri timi»ôorene"], in ''[[Realitatea EvreiascƒÉ]]'', n.360‚Äì361/2011, p.4</ref>
After his move, Rainer began expanding the scope of his contribution, and passed on to his students a particular view of science, decisively materialistic, [[Rationalism|rationalist]], and anti-[[Metaphysics|metaphysical]].<ref>BrƒÉtescu, p.102, 154; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.16‚Äì18, 43‚Äì46, 81‚Äì82, 90‚Äì93, 96‚Äì97, 110, 156‚Äì192; Vitner, pp.101‚Äì102, 105‚Äì106</ref> In particular, Rainer rejected the [[Intuition (Bergson)|intuitionism]] of [[Henri Bergson]], which had enjoyed a surge in popularity.<ref>Vitner, p.107</ref> His intellectual heroes and models of researchers included [[Claude Bernard]], [[Rudolf Virchow]], and especially Goethe.<ref>Majuru, p.287, 289; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.16, 18, 64, 110, 113, 122‚Äì123, 125‚Äì128, 131‚Äì132, 178</ref> The physician and left-wing political figure [[Ion Vitner]] writes that Rainer's understanding of the human body, heavily influenced by the work of [[Wilhelm Roux]], centered on "life", "movement", "function", and ultimately "[[ontogenesis]]", rather than on the "static catalog" of 19th-century anatomy.<ref>Vitner, pp.102‚Äì104. See also BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, p.13; Majuru, p.285; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.83‚Äì84, 103, 106‚Äì139</ref>
This worldview seeped into Rainer's research, which assumed the existence of a "precise genetic program" in man's [[Somatic effort|somatic development]].<ref>BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, p.13</ref> He centered his attention on correlating the activities of various organs and their understanding as "functional structures".<ref>Majuru, p.285; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.129‚Äì139; Vitner, pp.104‚Äì106</ref> This helped him and his students make groundbreaking discoveries in area such as the [[dura mater]], [[cranial nerves]], the [[lateral aortic lymph nodes]], and the [[hypophyseal portal system]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.137‚Äì139; Vitner, pp.104‚Äì106</ref> In his study of [[spondylopathy]], Rainer personally documented the existence of [[arthritis]] in the [[Atlas (anatomy)|atlas]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.138</ref>
Physician I. Spielmann describes Rainer admiringly as a "[[Polymath|polyhistor]]" with "a passionate image of what truth is".<ref>Majuru, p.287</ref> According to a student, the historian of medicine [[G. BrƒÉtescu]], Rainer was an outstanding pedagogue and public speaker, whose anatomy lessons were highly inspirational, but whose neglect for his public appearance could alienate young people.<ref>BrƒÉtescu, pp.74, 95, 97, 98, 101, 154, 285</ref> As he writes: "After showing us that medical science is one of observation, but that in practice it involves continuous experimentation, and why it is more of a craft that demands medical instinct, Rainer provided us with the one effective measure to sustain it: uninterrupted self-examination".<ref>BrƒÉtescu, p.95</ref> Vitner also noted Rainer's preference for orality, attributing it to an "extraordinary fear of the written word".<ref>Vitner, pp.100‚Äì101</ref> Meanwhile, other specialists rejected Rainer's ideas and approach. According to anatomist [[Victor Papilian]] (whom Rainer had denounced as a plagiarist), Rainer's was "a sterile and envious school" of self-proclaimed "geniuses". According to Papilian, Rainer moved freely between subjects outside of his competence, including the paleontology of [[Leonardo da Vinci]] and the latest discoveries in astronomy.<ref name="rconst39">{{ro icon}} Richard Constantinescu, [https://web.archive.org/web/20140714184531/http://rmr.medica.ro/reviste_med/download/rmr/2011.1/RMR_Nr-1_2011_Art-8.pdf "Grigore T. Popa »ôi Victor Papilian √Æntre 'juriu de onoare' »ôi polemicƒÉ"], in ''Revista MedicalƒÉ Rom√¢nƒÉ'', n.1/2011, p.39</ref>
Despite his progressive withdrawal from public life, Rainer was slowly being discovered as a public intellectual. In addition to his work at the university, he was again involved with ''Via»õa Rom√¢neascƒÉ'', and, from 1920, was one of the magazine's trustees.<ref name="Riga & CƒÉlin, p.63">Riga & CƒÉlin, p.63</ref> He taught [[kinesiology]] at the [[National Academy of Physical Education and Sport|Physical Education Institute]], and artistic anatomy at the [[Bucharest National University of Arts|School of Fine Arts]].<ref>Majuru, pp.282‚Äì283, 284‚Äì285; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.75, 186‚Äì191</ref> His lectures in anthropology, hosted by the Physical Education Institute from 1923, are believed to be the oldest form of anthropological education in Romania.<ref>Majuru, pp.282‚Äì283, 286</ref> Also that year, Rainer made a noted contribution to [[biological anthropology]], publishing his finds on the medieval princely remains dug up in [[Curtea de Arge»ô]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.84, 150</ref> He pursued other such investigations into the Romanian past, including the [[craniometry]] of [[Michael the Brave]] and the description of ancient tombs dug up at [[Drobeta-Turnu Severin|Turnu Severin]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.94, 150‚Äì151</ref>
Pursuing her own career in Bucharest hospitals, Marta was later a personal physician of [[Helen of Greece and Denmark|Helen of Greece]], wife of [[King of Romania|King]] [[Carol II of Romania]].<ref>BrƒÉtescu, p.125</ref> In their personal life, the Rainers experienced disappointment: having received her education in Romania, Sofia Rainer left for England, to attend the [[University of Bristol]]; she grew estranged from the family after her marriage to an Englishman, Archibald Philip Laing Gordon.<ref name="anmarta3"/>
===Biological anthropology=== [[File:Rainer, 1928. MƒÉsuratoare la Fundu Moldovei.jpg|thumb|240px|Rainer performing [[anthropometry]] at [[Fundu Moldovei]] (1928)]] Rainer's views eventually placed him at odds with the emerging far-right and [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] movement of the 1920s. At a time when the Ia»ôi-based [[National-Christian Defense League]] (LANC), seeking to purge [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jews]] from Romanian universities, was gaining momentum in Bucharest, a student identified Rainer as a Jew, and issued claims denying merit to his scholarship.<ref name="rconst39"/> According to Vitner, Rainer was the diametrical opposite of a Ia»ôi rival, the racist and LANC affiliate [[Nicolae Paulescu]], who stood for "dark and backward [[scientism]]".<ref>Vitner, p.101</ref> Vitner also recalls that Rainer was even shot at by far-right affiliates, so that he would no longer popularize his "democratic convictions".<ref>Vitner, pp.107‚Äì108</ref> For a while, Rainer was under the permanent protection of a [[Gendarmerie (Romania)|Gendarme]] guard.<ref name="rconst39"/>
Nevertheless, Rainer was himself an active proponent of "[[Genetic determinism|hereditary determinism]]" and [[eugenics]], which he understood as the cornerstone of social welfare policy.<ref>Bucur, pp.78‚Äì79, 110, 293‚Äì294. See also Majuru, p.285</ref> As he put it: "In the colorful mass of genes that carry those characteristics we inherit from our forerunners, one may find embedded [...] even our very destinies as men."<ref name="amaj282"/> A committed [[Physiognomy|physiognomist]],<ref>BrƒÉtescu, pp.102‚Äì103</ref> he believed that "only the [[phenotype]] may be influenced, to a certain extent, by our environment and our education."<ref name="amaj282"/> In June 1929, the newspaper ''[[AdevƒÉrul]]'' published one of Rainer's critical essays on the [[Land reform in Romania|1923 land reform]]. In it, Rainer claimed that the system of land reallocation had proved ignorant of eugenic and [[Biopolitics|biopolitical]] principles.<ref>Bucur, pp.78‚Äì79, 143, 327, 356</ref> Nevertheless, as readers of his work suggests, Rainer helped preserve a balance in anthropology by also looking into [[Environmental determinism|environmental factors]], thus questioning the ideological supremacy of [[scientific racism]].<ref>Vitner, p.105; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.147‚Äì149</ref>
During the 1920s and early '30s, Rainer was often depressed, believing that his contribution to medical science was largely insignificant.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.76, 77, 79‚Äì80</ref> He was also upset that various of his disciples, including [[Daniel Danielopolu]], no longer acknowledged him in their own tracts about the "science of life", which seemed to him a case of [[plagiarism]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.113‚Äì117</ref> He was dividing his time between Bucharest and the resort of [[Cheia]], where he owned a small piece of property.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.190‚Äì191</ref>
Subsequently, Rainer mainly focused on anthropological work and the popularization of anthropological science. Alongside sociologists such as [[Dimitrie Gusti]], [[Henri H. Stahl]], [[Sabin ManuilƒÉ]], [[Mircea VulcƒÉnescu]] and [[Xenia Costa-Foru]], he was present on the teaching staff of Veturia ManuilƒÉ's private school, where he gave lectures in anatomy to all-female classes preparing for a career in social services.<ref>Bucur, pp.15, 238‚Äì240; Stahl, p.190</ref> Between 1928 and 1932, Rainer was also involved in Gusti's [[rural sociology]] project in the [[Carpathians]]. Joining the Gusti team as an [[Anthropometry|anthropometrist]], he earned kudos from the scientific community of his day with ''Enqu√™tes anthropologiques dans trois villages roumains des Carpathes'' ("Anthropological Queries in Three Romanian Villages of the Carpathians").<ref>Bucur, p.78; Majuru, p.287; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.87‚Äì89, 152</ref> Published in 1937, it remains one of just four testimonials written by members of Gusti's team.<ref>»öone, pp.64, 65</ref>
While on location in [[Nereju]], [[DrƒÉgu»ô]] and [[Fundu Moldovei]], he expanded the canon of anthropometry, and began recording [[blood type]], investigated the presence and spread of [[syphilis]], and provided free medical consultations to the peasants.<ref>Majuru, pp.286‚Äì287; Stahl, pp.48, 68‚Äì69, 88‚Äì90, 106, 148, 175; »öone, ''passim''</ref> Rainer and his specialist unit, including [[Social hygiene movement|social hygienists]], documented the squalid conditions of rural life. At Fundu Moldovei, where some of the villages were entirely cut off from the outside world, Rainer found that up to 50% of his samples showed contamination with syphilis, forcing him to distribute reserves of [[neosalvarsan]].<ref>»öone, pp.66, 71‚Äì72</ref> Stahl, who befriended Rainer in Fundu Moldovei, recalls that the stated purpose of Rainer's visit was an attempt to bridge physiology and sociology: "he did not yet see what that connection might be, but any research should be carried out rigorously, so that, who knows, another generation, more skilled than we are, might come along and use it."<ref>Stahl, p.89</ref>
Rainer's anthropometric work, which used for a permanent record peasant photographs, in large part taken by Milcu,<ref>BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, pp.18, 19</ref> remains a problematic aspect of Gustian sociology. As noted by cultural historian [[Z. Ornea]] (based on Stahl's recollections), Rainer "carried out unperturbed his anthropometric research, although he was not an adept of racial science and had no idea of what this anthropometry and blood chemistry [...] were going to be used for. And yet, the great professor of histology would return annually to the villages that were studied by the monographic teams and to carry out this research with no purpose and no finality."<ref name="zointerviu">{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/un_interviu_incitant_cu_h.h._stahl "Un interviu incitant cu H.H. Stahl"], in ''[[Rom√¢nia LiterarƒÉ]]'', n.23/2001</ref> Anthropologist [[VintilƒÉ MihƒÉilescu]] also notes that the combination of Gusti's sociology and Rainer's physical anthropology was a "domestic [[ethnology]]", "self-referential" and "biased", but nevertheless an "important tool" for later cultural anthropology.<ref>MihƒÉilescu, pp.210‚Äì211</ref>
Rainer also made frequent trips to Western Europe and the [[Balkans]]. He was in [[Sweden]] during 1930, attending the Physiological Congress as a Physical Education Institute delegate, and paying a visit to the [[Statens institut f√∂r rasbiologi|Racial Biology Institute]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.75‚Äì76, 189‚Äì190</ref> In 1931 and again in 1933, he was in [[Second Hellenic Republic|Greece]] together with sculptor [[Mac Constantinescu]], gathering material about artistic depictions of humans in the [[Mycenaean Greece|Mycenaean period]].<ref>H√Ænganu, p.159; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.76</ref> In 1935, he lectured at the [[Romanian Atheneum]] on the links between [[Platonism]] and modern science, being introduced there by zoologist [[Constantin Kiri»õescu]] (one of several popularization conferences Rainer held at the Atheneum, Dalles Hall, and in various provincial cities).<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.15, 16, 90‚Äì94</ref> He kept his depression under control by taking trips to Turkey, and again to Greece, where he dedicated himself to the study of customs and classical art.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.76‚Äì78</ref> Upon his return, Rainer opened his bone collection for the public, as a permanent museum, during the Bucharest International Congress of Anthropology and Prehistorical Archeology, 1937. It comprised some 6,000 bone relics and casts.<ref>Majuru, p.287. See also Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.84‚Äì86</ref>
===Final years=== [[File:Regina-mamƒÉ Elena »ôi Regele Mihai I viziteazƒÉ Institutul de antropologie √Æn toamna anului 1940.jpg|thumb|300px|Rainer at his anthropological research center, alongside [[King of Romania|King]] [[Michael I of Romania|Michael I]] and [[Helen of Greece and Denmark|Queen Helen]] (autumn 1940)]] With his activity in academia, Rainer reacted against [[cronyism]], taking a public stand against arbitrary appointments in teaching, and ruining his relationship with the establishment.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.79-80</ref> At a time when the Romanian school of anthropology was being divided between centrists and supporters of the [[Fascism|fascist]] [[Iron Guard]],<ref name="zointerviu"/><ref>Stahl, pp.23, 143‚Äì144, 157, 185, 214‚Äì221, 299‚Äì300, 313‚Äì315, 332‚Äì333</ref> he was again confronted by the far-right. Rainer was opposed to the fascist youth, whose members instigated in favor of academic censorship in his university curriculum. At one such incident in early 1938, Rainer stood unmoved at his desk as some of his fascist students, including the son of painter [[Nicolae Tonitza]],<ref name="mnbnegru"/> lit firecrackers and threw eggs in his direction. However, he refused to ask for sanctions against them, and eventually received their letter of apology.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.80‚Äì81</ref>
After 1939, although Romania was formally aligned with [[Nazi Germany]], Rainer spoke out against [[Nazism and race|Nazi racial science]]. In his public lectures, he dismissed the Nazi claim that [[cephalic index]]es were good predictors of intelligence.<ref>BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, p.16</ref> His publicized texts, deemed "courageous" by historian Adrian Majuru, accepted the idea of race, but denied the concept of a "pure race", rejected the scientific claims of [[Aryan race|Aryanism]], and argued that European civilization owed its existence to [[Semitic peoples]].<ref>Majuru, p.286. See also Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.89, 145‚Äì148</ref> According to Rainer, races were rather phenotypical isolates of only one species, the ''[[Anatomically modern humans|homo sapiens recens]]'', of the same genetic age; there existed no racial hierarchy.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.145‚Äì147</ref>
In 1940, at the height of [[World War II]], Rainer helped establish an anthropological research center of which he was honorary director until his death.<ref name="institutul">{{ro icon}} [http://www.antropologia.ro/Istoric Istoric] at the Institutul de Antropologie Francisc I. Rainer al Academiei Rom√¢ne site</ref><ref>H√Ænganu, p.159; Majuru, p.286; MihƒÉilescu, pp.210‚Äì211; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.84‚Äì87, 140</ref> That year, he and his institution were admitted into the French Prehistoric Society.<ref>"Conseil d'Administration pour les ann√©es 1940 et 1941", in ''Bulletin de la Soci√©t√© Pr√©historique de France'', 38, n.1‚Äì2/1941, p.4</ref> In 1941, following Romania's entry, alongside Germany, in the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|war against the Soviet Union]], Rainer obtained that his team of doctors be spared conscription.<ref name="mnbnegru"/>
Later that year, Rainer retired from teaching, having reached the age limit. The students demanded and obtained that he be allowed to hold additional lectures in general and human biology, despite Rainer's problematic deafness.<ref name="mnbnegru"/><ref>BrƒÉtescu, pp.101‚Äì103, 106, 113‚Äì116; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.91</ref> Meanwhile, G. T. Popa, who had continued Rainer's anatomical work in Ia»ôi between 1928 and 1942, took over his chair in Bucharest.<ref>H√Ænganu, pp.160‚Äì161</ref> Tensions between Popa and his mentor were already showing in public,<ref>BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, p.18; BrƒÉtescu, p.105</ref> with Popa fending off accusations that he had taken credit for Rainer's work on the [[hypophyseal portal system]].<ref>Popa, ''passim''; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.138</ref>
In May 1943, Rainer was made an honorary member of the [[Romanian Academy]].<ref name="r&c99">Riga & CƒÉlin, p.99</ref> He continued to publish anthropological contributions, including a 1942 description (with [[Ion Th. Simionescu]] as the co-author) of the [[Pe»ôtera Muierilor|Cioclovina Skull]], the first such [[paleolithic]] discovery on Romanian soil.<ref>[[Dumitru Berciu]], "DƒÉri de seamƒÉ. Fr. Rainer »ôi I. Simionescu, ''Sur le premier cr√¢ne d'homme pal√©olithique trouv√© en Roumanie''", in ''Revista IstoricƒÉ'', n.7‚Äì12/1943, pp.297‚Äì298; Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.144, 150</ref> He also contributed a chapter on "the living substance" to [[Victor V√¢lcovici]]'s 1943 synthesis, ''Materia »ôi via»õa'' ("Matter and Life").<ref>N. BƒÉrbulescu, "Cronici. ''Materia »ôi via»õa''", in ''[[G√¢ndirea]]'', n.4‚Äì5/1944, p.239; Riga & CƒÉlin, p.195</ref> He was still an outspoken adversary of the Nazi regime. Maintaining a philosophical correspondence with the medievalist [[Alphonse Dupront]], who was stranded in [[German military administration in occupied France during World War II|occupied France]], he described the Nazi age as an "empire of suffering", reaffirming his conviction in "the future of mankind".<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.96</ref> He was among the signers of a letter of protest, addressed to dictator [[Ion Antonescu]], which questioned Romania's participation in the anti-Soviet war.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.18</ref>
During the same months, Rainer diagnosed himself with [[lung cancer]], which was another probable effect of his long exposure to formaldehyde fumes.<ref name="r&c99"/> He tried to hide this from his wife and his friends, claiming his problem was a mere case of [[Vocal cord paresis|paresis]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.99‚Äì100</ref> His house was narrowly missed by the [[Bombing of Bucharest in World War II|April 1944 bombardment]], and he had to move into the house of a former assistant, [[Ion »öurai]]. He was later moved to Hospital No. 303, where he developed [[metastasis]] in the brain.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, p.100</ref>
Rainer asked to be relocated to his townhouse, where he died on the morning of August 4, 1944. He had predicted the exact time of his death, and written precise instructions for his body's [[embalming]].<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.100, 101</ref> This occurred just nineteen days before the [[King Michael's Coup|Palace Coup]] that ended Romania's alliance with the [[Axis Powers]]. With the onset of [[Soviet occupation of Romania|Soviet occupation]], Rainer's left-wing stances were highlighted in his official commemoration. BrƒÉtescu, who was also a [[Union of Communist Youth|Communist Youth]] militant, published such homages in the newspaper ''Tribuna Poporului'', and spoke about Rainer at the Students' Society.<ref>BrƒÉtescu, pp.122‚Äì124, 134</ref> In the latter address, he emphasized that Rainer had been an [[Antifascism|antifascist]] and a reader of political works by [[Joseph Stalin]].<ref>BrƒÉtescu, p.134</ref>
==Legacy== Rainer was generally well regarded by the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]], which existed in Romania until the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|1989 Revolution]]. His texts on science and society were collected and preserved, against Rainer's final wish that they should all be burned.<ref name="Riga & CƒÉlin, p.63"/> Some were carried in the first issues of ''[[Contemporanul]]'' review, from September 1946.<ref>[[Ioan LƒÉcustƒÉ]], "√én Bucure»ôti, acum 50 de ani", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', September 1996, p.31</ref> In 1948, the corpus was published by the Academy as four volumes, together with critical essays and memoirs edited by Marta Rainer and [[Mihail Sevastos]].<ref>Vitner, p.100. See also Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.5‚Äì6, 14‚Äì15</ref> However, his anthropological museum, assigned to Popa and later to Milcu, was poorly staffed by the communist supervisors and faced closure. Communist supervisors such as [[Mihail Roller]] suspected that Rainer had created the anthropology research center to promote racism, but Milcu was able to convince them otherwise, and even obtained funds for an anthropological study of [[Origin of the Romanians|Romanian ethnogenesis]].<ref>BƒÉlƒÉceanu-Stolnici, pp.15‚Äì16</ref> Despite other political obstacles and the communist rejection of anthropology as an "abstract intellectual game", cultural anthropologist Vasile Caramelea was able to obtain approval for further research, and expanded the institute's contribution to social science.<ref>MihƒÉilescu, p.212</ref>
A biography of Rainer was published by Ilie Th. Riga, in 1966, at [[Editura »òtiin»õificƒÉ]]. It revealed to the public glimpses of Rainer's diaries, which had been preserved by Marta Rainer.<ref>Riga & CƒÉlin, pp.5‚Äì6</ref> Another encomium, signed by Th. EnƒÉchescu, saw print in the academic journal ''Studii »ôi CercetƒÉri Antopologice'' in 1970.<ref>BrƒÉtescu, p.318</ref> In 1979, at [[Editura Eminescu]], BrƒÉtescu and Mihai Neagu Basarab published Rainer's diaries and letters, which were received with great interest by the intellectual community, including [[Geo Bogza]], [[Constantin Noica]] and [[Nicolae Steinhardt]],<ref>BrƒÉtescu, pp.343, 365</ref> but less enthusiastically by the general public. As later noted by BrƒÉtescu, regular readers found Rainer's thoughts on "the coherence of the Cosmos" to be "pretentious banalities".<ref>BrƒÉtescu, p.344</ref>
Rainer continued to be held in high regard after the Revolution, when light was shed on various other aspects of his work. A 2001 exhibit of his skulls collection at Galeria Catacomba made a point of reintroducing his work to the cultural circles of the day.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Pavel »òu»ôarƒÉ]], [http://www.romlit.ro/un_patrimoniu_de_scfrlii "Un patrimoniu de scƒÉf√Ærlii"], in ''[[Rom√¢nia LiterarƒÉ]]'', n.9/2001</ref> The anthropological center that Rainer helped established was renamed in his honor in 2007.<ref name="institutul"/>

[[File:Versailles Palace.jpg|thumb|300px|The Palace of Versailles where the formal presentations for ladies took place]]
The '''Honneurs de la Cour''' ('''Honors of the Court''') were ceremonious presentations to the sovereign at the [[Palace of Versailles|Royal Court of France]] that were formal for women but more casual for men. It was an honour granted only to the families of [[Noblesse d'√©p√©e|ancient nobility]]. It allowed them to approach the [[King of France|King]] and the [[Queen of France|Queen]] of France.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isgn.fr/autres/img358a.pdf |title=Notice historique sur les honneurs de la Cour |language=French |publisher=Institution Saint Georges pour la Noblesse |quote=...''(etre admis aux) honneurs de la Cour, c'est-a-dire aux cercles, aux receptions, aux bals du Roi et de la Reine, pour monter dans les carrosses de Sa majeste et l'accompagner a la chasse''; in English: ''[the Honors of the Court meant] to be allow to attend the circles, receptions and balls of the King and the Queen, to get into His Majesty's carriages and to go hunting with the King''. |year=2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721001229/http://www.isgn.fr/autres/img358a.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref>
==Overview== The Honors of the Court "were the most prestigious noble honour of the 18th century, meant to honour the most ancient and representing noble families".<ref name="Valette">R√©gis Valette, ''Catalogue de la noblesse fran√ßaise au XXIe si√®cle'', √©d. Robert Laffont, Paris, 2007</ref>
Formally such presentations were only granted to noble families able to prove a lineage dating back to 1400 A.D. without tracks of ennoblement. However, the king could grant exemptions to families that had been dedicated to serve him. He could also refuse a valid candidate with sufficient nobility whose family was not involved enough in the king's wars as nobles were primarily mounted warriors who had sworn allegiance to their sovereign and promised to fight for him. On a list of candidates he would then place a remark next to the name of the refused applicant saying "ne se peut" (can't be) or "attendre" (wait).
The Honors of the Court should not be mistaken for court life. The oldest nobility did not always match the court nobility. Many families living at court were descendants from [[Noblesse de robe|less ancient nobility]] while many nobles of [[Noblesse d'√©p√©e|antique nobility]] did not stay at court. Moreover, life at the Versailles Court was expensive and many were unable to afford it.
The nobleman who was granted the presentation would follow a royal hunt on board of one of the king's carriages. At that point he would be casually introduced to the king. A noblewoman's presentation was much more formal, taking place during a specific ceremony.
From 1715 to 1790,<ref>The ''Honneurs'' were codified in 1715 (the first year of [[Louis XV]]'s reign), there were no more presentation after the [[French Revolution|fall of the monarchy]] in 1790.</ref> 942 families were granted the Honors of the Court; 880 of them were French. Fran√ßois Bluche, who studied the royal genealogical archives, said that among the 942 families "462 were able to prove a noble lineage dating back to 1400, if excluding sovereign houses and foreign nobles who, unlike one can think, made up more than half of the French nobleman received at Court".<ref name="Bluche">{{cite magazine|first=Fran√ßois |last=Bluche |title=Les Honneurs de la Cour |location=Paris | series=Les Cahiers nobles |date=1957 |magazine=[[L'interm√©diaire des Chercheurs et des Curieux]]}}</ref> He has limited his work to a list of 43 [[Noble family|Houses]] especially flattered by the King's archive, these 43 families are considered of major regional or national importance and members of the highest 18th century nobility.
According to R√©gis Valette<ref name="Valette"/> only 280 of the 880 French families who were granted the Honors of the Court still remain today.
== List of families who were granted the Honneurs de la Cour == [[File:Louis14-Versailles1685.jpg|thumb|center|400px|The 10-year-old Duke of Chartres in red on the right; the scene depicts the ''[[Doge]] of [[Genoa]] at [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] on the 15 May 1685''.]]
The following table provides an incomplete list of families who were granted the Honors of the Court, including dates (when available) and sources. The ones listed by Fran√ßois Bluche,<ref name="Bluche" /> considered the most prominent French noble families of the 18th century, are marked with bold script.

{{Other uses of|Individual mobility|Social identity theory}} {{Network Science}} Individual [[mobilities|human mobility]] is the study that describes how individual humans move within a network or system.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Keyfitz |first1=Nathan |title=Individual Mobility in a Stationary Population |journal=Population Studies |volume=27 |issue=July 1, 1973 |pages=335‚Äì352 |doi=10.2307/2173401 |jstor=2173401 |publisher=Taylor & Francis, Ltd.}}</ref> The concept has been researched by a number of fields originating in the study of demographics. Understanding human mobility has many applications in diverse areas, including [[spread of diseases]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Colizza | first1 = V. | last2 = Barrat | first2 = A. | last3 = Barth√©l√©my | first3 = M. | last4 = Valleron | first4 = A.-J. | last5 = Vespignani | first5 = A. | year = 2007 | title = Modeling the worldwide spread of pandemic influenza: baseline case and containment interventions | PMC=1779816 | journal = PLoS Medicine | volume = 4 | issue = | pages = 95‚Äì110 | pmid=17253899 | doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hufnagel | first1 = L. | last2 = Brockmann | first2 = D. | last3 = Geisel | first3 = T. | year = 2004 | title = Forecast and control of epidemics in a globalized world | url = | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA | volume = 101 | issue = | pages = 15124‚Äì15129 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0308344101| arxiv = cond-mat/0410766 | bibcode = 2004PNAS..10115124H }}</ref> [[mobile virus]]es,<ref>Epidemic spreading in scale-free networks. R Pastor-Satorras, A Vespignani - Physical review letters, 2001</ref> [[city planning]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Horner | first1 = M. W. | last2 = O'Kelly | first2 = M. E. S | year = 2001 | title = Embedding economies of scale concepts for hub networks design | url = | journal = J. Transp. Geogr | volume = 9 | issue = | pages = 255‚Äì265 | doi=10.1016/s0966-6923(01)00019-9}}</ref><ref>Inferring land use from mobile phone activity JL Toole, M Ulm, MC Gonz√°lez, D Bauer - Proceedings of the ACM SIGKDD international ‚Ä¶, 2012</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rozenfeld | first1 = H. D. | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2008 | title = Laws of population growth | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0807435105 | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA | volume = 105 | issue = | pages = 18702‚Äì18707 | arxiv = 0808.2202 | bibcode = 2008PNAS..10518702R }}</ref> [[traffic engineering (transportation)|traffic engineering]],<ref>P Wang, T Hunter, AM Bayen, K Schechtner "Understanding road usage patterns in urban areas" ''Scientific reports'', 2012</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Krings | first1 = G. | last2 = Calabrese | first2 = F. | last3 = Ratti | first3 = C. | last4 = Blondel | first4 = V. D. | year = | title = Urban gravity: A model for inter-city telecommunication flows | url = | journal = J. Stat. Mech.-Theor. Exp. | volume = L07003 | issue = | page = 2009 }}</ref> [[financial market forecasting]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gabaix | first1 = X. | last2 = Gopikrishnan | first2 = P. | last3 = Plerou | first3 = V. | last4 = Stanley | first4 = H. E. | year = 2003 | title = A theory of power-law distributions in financial market fluctuations | url = | journal = Nature | volume = 423 | issue = | pages = 267‚Äì270 | doi=10.1038/nature01624 | pmid=12748636| bibcode = 2003Natur.423..267G }}</ref> and [[nowcasting (economics)|nowcasting]] of economic [[well-being]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/jos.2015.31.issue-2/jos-2015-0017/jos-2015-0017.xml|title = Small Area Model-Based Estimators Using Big Data Sources|last = Stefano Marchetti|date = Jun 2015|journal = Journal of Official Statistics|doi = 10.1515/jos-2015-0017|pmid = |access-date = |display-authors=etal|volume=31}}</ref><ref>L. Pappalardo et al., [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282869681_Using_Big_Data_to_study_the_link_between_human_mobility_and_socio-economic_development Using Big Data to study the link between human mobility and socio-economic development], Proceedings of the 2015 IEEE International conference on Big Data, Santa Clara, CA, USA, 2015.</ref>
== Data == In recent years, there has been a surge in large data sets available on human movements. These data sets are usually obtained from [[cell phone tracking|cell phone]] or [[GPS tracking|GPS]] data, with varying degrees of accuracy. For example, cell phone data is usually recorded whenever a call or a text message has been made or received by the user, and contains the location of the tower that the phone has connected to as well as the time stamp.<ref name=marta /> In urban areas, user and the telecommunication tower might be only a few hundred meters away from each other, while in rural areas this distance might well be in region of a few kilometers. Therefore, there is varying degree of accuracy when it comes to locating a person using cell phone data. These datasets are anonymized by the phone companies so as to hide and protect the identity of actual users. As example of its usage, researchers <ref name=marta /> used the trajectory of 100,000 cell phone users within a period of six months, while in much larger scale <ref name=song /> trajectories of three million cell phone users were analyzed. GPS data are usually much more accurate even though they usually are, because of [[privacy]] concerns, much harder to acquire. Massive amounts of GPS data describing human mobility are produced, for example, by on-board GPS devices on private vehicles.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150908/ncomms9166/full/ncomms9166.html|title = Returners and Explorers dichotomy in Human Mobility|last = Luca Pappalardo|date = 8 September 2015|journal = Nature Communications|doi = 10.1038/ncomms9166|pmid = 26349016|volume = 6|display-authors=etal|pages=8166|pmc=4569739|bibcode=2015NatCo...6E8166P}}</ref> The GPS device automatically turns on when the vehicle starts, and the sequence of GPS points the device produces every few seconds forms a detailed mobility trajectory of the vehicle. Some recent scientific studies compared the mobility patterns emerged from mobile phone data with those emerged from GPS data.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>L. Pappalardo et al., [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6855925&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D6855925 Comparing general mobility and mobility by car], BRICS Countries Congress (BRICS-CCI) and 11th Brazilian Congress (CBIC) on Computational Intelligence, 2013.</ref>
Researchers have been able to extract very detailed information about the people whose data are made available to public. This has sparked a great amount of concern about privacy issues. As an example of liabilities that might happen, [[New York City]] released 173 million individual [[taxi]] trips. City officials used a very weak [[cryptography algorithm]] to anonymize the license number and medallion number, which is an alphanumeric code assigned to each taxi cab.<ref name=gawker>{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/the-public-nyc-taxicab-database-that-accidentally-track-1646724546 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141118175119/http://gawker.com/the-public-nyc-taxicab-database-that-accidentally-track-1646724546 |archivedate=2014-11-18 |df= }}</ref> This made it possible for hackers to completely de-anonymize the dataset, and even some were able to extract detailed information about specific passengers and celebrities, including their origin and destination and how much they tipped.<ref name=gawker /><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/27/new-york-taxi-details-anonymised-data-researchers-warn</ref>
== Characteristics == At the large scale, when the behaviour is modelled over a period of relatively long duration (e.g. more than one day), human mobility can be described by three major components: * trip distance distribution <math> P(r) </math> * radius of [[gyration]] <math> r_g (t)</math> * number of visited locations <math> S(t) </math>
Brockmann,<ref>The scaling laws of human travel. D Brockmann, L Hufnagel, T Geisel - Nature, 2006 - nature.com</ref> by analysing banknotes, found that the probability of travel distance follows a [[scale-free network|scale-free]] [[random walk]] known as [[L√©vy flight]] of form <math> P(r)\ \sim r^{-(1+\beta)} </math> where <math>\beta =0.6 </math>. This was later confirmed by two studies that used cell phone data<ref name=marta /> and GPS data to track users.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1140%2Fepjst%2Fe2013-01715-5|title = Understanding the patterns of car travel|last = Luca Pappalardo|date = 29 January 2013|journal = European Physical Journal ST|doi = 10.1140/epjst/e2013-01715-5|pmid = |access-date = |volume = 215|issue = 1|display-authors=etal|pages=61‚Äì73|bibcode = 2013EPJST.215...61P}}</ref> The implication of this model is that, as opposed to other more traditional forms of random walks such as [[brownian motion]], human trips tend to be of mostly short distances with a few long distance ones. In brownian motion, the distribution of trip distances are govern by a bell-shaped curve, which means that the next trip is of a roughly predictable size, the average, where in L√©vy flight it might be an order of magnitude larger than the average.
Some people are inherently inclined to travel longer distances than the average, and the same is true for people with lesser urge for movement. Radius of gyration is used to capture just that and it indicates the characteristic distance travelled by a person during a time period t.<ref name=marta>Understanding individual human mobility patterns MC Gonzalez, CA Hidalgo, AL Barabasi - Nature, 2008</ref> Each user, within his radius of gyration <math> r_g (t)</math>, will choose his trip distance according to <math> P(r) </math>.
The third component models the fact that humans tend to visit some locations more often than what would have happened under a random scenario. For example, home or workplace or favorite restaurants are visited much more than many other places in a user's radius of gyration. It has been discovered that <math> S(t)\ \sim t^{\mu} </math> where <math> \mu = 0.6 </math>, which indicates a sublinear growth in different number of places visited by an individual . These three measures capture the fact that most trips happen between a limited number of places, with less frequent travels to places outside of an individual's radius of gyration.
== Predictability == Although the human mobility is modeled as a random process, it is surprisingly predictable. By measuring the entropy of each person's movement, it has been shown <ref name=song>Limits of predictability in human mobility. C Song, Z Qu, N Blumm, AL Barab√°si - Science, 2010</ref> that there is a 93% potential predictability. This means that although there is a great variance in type of users and the distances that each of them travel, the overall characteristic of them is highly predictable. Implication of it is that in principle, it is possible to accurately model the processes that are dependent on human mobility patterns, such as disease or mobile virus spreading patterns.<ref name=airtransportation>A metric of influential spreading during contagion dynamics through the air transportation network C Nicolaides, L Cueto-Felgueroso, MC Gonz√°lez‚Ä¶ - PLoS ONE, 2012</ref><ref name=phonevirus>Understanding the spreading patterns of mobile phone viruses P Wang, MC Gonz√°lez, CA Hidalgo, AL Barab√°si - Science, 2009</ref><ref>Colizza, V., Barrat, A., Barth√©lemy, M. & Vespignani, A. Predictability and epidemic pathways in global outbreaks of infectious diseases: The SARS case study. BMC Med. 5, 34 (2007)</ref>
On individual scale, daily human mobility can be explained by only 17 [[Network motif]]s. Each individual, shows one of these motifs characteristically, over a period of several months. This opens up the possibility to reproduce daily individual mobility using a tractable analytical model<ref>Unravelling daily human mobility motifs CM Schneider, V Belik, T Couronn√©, Z Smoreda‚Ä¶ - Journal of The Royal Society Interface, 2013</ref>
== Applications == [[Infectious disease]]s spread across the globe usually because of long-distance travels of carriers of the disease. These long-distance travels are made using [[air transport]]ation systems and it has been shown that "[[network topology]], traffic structure, and individual mobility patterns are all essential for accurate predictions of disease spreading".<ref name=airtransportation/> On a smaller spatial scale the regularity of human movement patterns and its temporal structure should be taken into account in models of infectious disease spread.<ref name=commuting>V Belik, T Geisel, D Brockmann, Natural human mobility patterns and spatial spread of infectious diseases. Phys. Rev. X, 2011</ref> Cellphone viruses that are transmitted via bluetooth are greatly dependent on the human interaction and movements. With more people using similar operating systems for their cellphones, it's becoming much easier to have a virus epidemic.<ref name=phonevirus />
In [[Transportation Planning]], leveraging the characteristics of human movement, such as tendency to travel short distances with few but regular bursts of long-distance trips, novel improvements have been made to [[Trip distribution]] models, specifically to [[Gravity model of migration]] <ref>A universal model for mobility and migration patterns F Simini, MC Gonz√°lez, A Maritan, AL Barab√°si - Nature, 2012</ref>
